number of helpful: 3 of 4 people (75%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: November 27, 2013
												Defender's Quest is a novel rpg take on the tower defense genre. That in and of itself would make an interesting game, but the designers saw fit to include an interesting story to explain away the game mechanics as part of the plot. While the central theme of plague and the risen dead is dark, the dialogue between characters is lighthearted and oftentimes funny. Such a combination of serious undertones and bright interplay amongst the characters helped me enjoy the game quite a bit.Insofar as the actual mechanics are concerned, this is not a "maze building" tower defense game. The enemies will come in waves along pre-defined paths with limited placement for your defenders (the towers, essentially) available. Defenders can be upgraded by "boosting" them through five levels which unlocks any abilities they may have earned through levelling and a rudimentary talent system. Speaking of levelling, this is where the rpg mechanic comes into play; every level gained by a defender gives you talent points which you can use to tweak the character and gain new abilities. While the talent system is very basic, it does give you a feeling of satisfaction to distribute your points when a defender levels or you gain access to a new class. While there are only six classes of defender to use in the game, the customization inherent in the rpg progression system means there is the possibility of some differentiation. Additional defenders can be recruited in towns across the game's story map, wherein the plot is advanced and new battlefields are opened up. In battle, these defenders are placed with the same resource you use for upgrading, but recruiting new defenders gets progressively expensive with the game's story mode currency (won through battle). That same currency is used for equipping your defenders with weapons and armor, so there is an opportunity cost. As additional currency can be won by going back and fighting harder versions of prior story mode battles at any time, you never truly feel strapped for cash.As the game is 2d, the question isn't whether the graphics are advanced, but how good and cohesive they look. Cut scenes to advance the plot are drawn with a style which gels extremely well with the battle sprites and look pleasing to the eye. Opinions on art styles will vary, but the cleanliness and cohesiveness of the game's visuals can not be denied. There are no sloppy looking sprites in this game and your defender's colors can even be customized to a limited degree to further suit your tastes. Unfortunately, while the animations of your defenders (and especially that of a certain antagonist at the very end of the game) are fluid and pleasing to watch, the animations of the monsters which you are tasked to kill are very basic and stilted. Still, most of the time said monsters are drowning in a sea of pleasing damage numbers as your defenders are chopping them to pieces, so perhaps some gamers will be able to overlook this as I did.According to steam, I was able to extract 13 hours out of this game and there are still bonus challenges to complete and a new game plus mode to experiment with. Whether that is worth the price of admission is a decision that I encourage you to weigh carefully if you would normally pass up a game based on length: it is lovingly crafted and an enjoyable experience that I can recommend to any rpg fan, even those who aren't familliar with tower defense games.The long and short of it: 8/10, buy it.

content:
Posted: February 12
Defender's Quest: Valley of the Forgotten (DX edition) is a fun yet somehow shallow tower defense game. It's one of these cases where Steam's binary review system forces me to give a 'thumbs up' rating followed by a long text with all the caveats.TLDRIf you're looking for a relaxed, not-to-deep tower defense with colorful graphics, thematic music and some tongue-in-cheek dialog you might try this out. If you're looking for the best-in-class tower defense game, this is not it.detailsThe game has us accompany Azra, the royal librarian of a fantasy land, through her journey across the land where she must overcome various evils. You wouldn't play this game for its story per se but the dialogs and well crafted scenery and overworld make for a compelling reason to keep playing. Via overlay tutorials the player is introduced gently into the actual gameplay of placing and managing your figthers. While the start is great you soon realize that there isn't a lot of depth to the gameplay. I've played Warcraft 3 custom maps that had more mechanical variety in their tower defense than this game.The mechanics merit a closer look because they are the Achilles' heel of this game really. There just isn't a lot to do other than the basics : placing your figthers (towers) and upgrading them, using your global hero powers now an dthen. There's no option to call a wave early for extra cash, no towers that teleport mobs to the beginning of the maze, no flying units that ignore the ground paths altogether, no possiblity to send your own troops against the enemy, etc., etc.Mostly you'll be fighting against zombie like creatures which is justified by the story but it gets stale fast. There's a missed opportunity here for including a much more diverse set of enemies that challenge the player to adjust their strategy and tactics.Outside of combat you'll have the opportunity to manage your party by purchasing equipment, acquiring new fighters up your fighters by assigning points in a talent tree. The game limits itself to 6 classes of figthers (towers) all of which are nicely integrated into and justified by the story. Every figther has a unique role and there's little possiblity of straying from that role via the talent tree. You want your archers exel at ranged combat and your freeze mages to excel at slowing down foes. That is that. I dare to say that this game suffers from a mild sort of RPG syndrome: the inclusion of RPG elements (experience bars, talent trees, interchangeable equipment) for the mere sake of it.The developers have included many interface features that are very useful in this type of game, like being able to slow or speed up time at will or being able to reuse your previous tower layout if you failed a mission. Being able to control the game's speed at will makes for relaxed play sessions and there's even the option to scale experience points and loot rewards if you feel the pace is to slow or to fast. One of the decisions that astonishes me is that the developers decided to hide away some content like side missions and additional dialog in new game plus (ng+) mode. Since this game's story and presentation are on the strong side (for this genre) this baffles me. I've tried my fair share of ng+ and In the way of difficulty or mechanics there isn't much that varants a second playtrough. Defender's Quest is rather the kind of game that you play through once to see the plot come to its conclusion and then move on to something else.This game supports the Steam controller ouf of the box and the layout is quite sensical. When using it though, the game would often hang in dialog scenes or null pointer crash. No such issues presented themselves however when playing with well though out keyboard layout.All in all, I've had my fun with Defender's Quest and I'm looking forward to see the devs expand upon it with Defender's Quest 2 which is currently in development.Edit: the game supports modding via the Steam workshop. While there aren't very many modifications available as of writing (February 2017) this is certainly a big plus!

number of helpful: 26 of 50 people (52%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: June 11, 2015
												Not a good game.It was as if the devs made sure it had all the elements to sell, but none to make it fun.Not an enjoyable 17 hours.  I wasn't smart enough to stop.(1)  The tower defense gameplay was poor.  The appeal of tower defense games is usually to try and optimize your defense to be efficient and effective as possible against the oncoming force.   In Defender's Quest there are very few places where your characters can be placed rationally.  In other words, there was only one strategy to place your characters when you setup.  Since there were no other real elements to the game, this made it very boring.  When you lost a mission, you couldn't try and refine your process as there was nothing to refine.  You just needed to level up to get stronger.(2)  The character leveling up process was poor.  I decided to buy the game because the game boasted an RPG leveling-up process.  Although this is technically true, you DO HAVE TO CLICK A BUTTON in order for them to get more powerful, it could have been done automatically as your choices were thin, uncreative, and obvious.  Again, there was no game element in it.  You put the point where it was supposed to go and done.(3)  The storyline was not worth it.  I don't remember the storyline other than it seemed shallow.  The characters were the best part of the game.  Each character seemed unique and full of personality, but the storyline needed more to take away from the poor gameplay.  Because I liked the characters and I thought they were unique, it was a big letdown to find out later that you get more characters just like them gameplay wise.  Here you thought you had a unique crazy berserker guy or a badass ice mage, but no, they are just one of many.(4)  The enemies were uncreative.  The enemies were similar across the board.  At no point do you need to change your strategy based on the different types of enemies coming our way.    Some tower defense games have VERY uncreative enemies, but they don't need varied enemies as the game element is in the placing of the towers/characters, abilities, and tower synergy.  Defender's Quest did not have that.

Posted: March 22, 2014
												A delightful indie gem, Defender's Quest combines some of the funniest writing I've seen in a game with a terrific twist on tower defence. The campaign is cleverly designed. Each battle has four difficulty levels. You can push through the storyline on a low level, and indeed you need to at the early stages. However, there is plenty of incentive to come back and try it again for special items, experience and rewards. Battles are short and varied so there is not really a sense of grinding; indeed, it is interesting to come back with new options through skills and classes.There is plenty of scope for strategy in the battles. There are six different classes, each having different skills and attributes which can be levelled up. They can be boosted during the battle, and can be recalled and replaced. There can be incredibly tense moments late in a battle when a powerful enemy is closing in and you have to frantically recall fighters to put them into better positions. The ability to pause or slow time means that success depends on your strategy, not your reflexes. The variety of battle maps and enemies make for a different experience in each battle. There are genuine laugh-out-loud moments throughout the campaign, which adds to the pleasurable experience of progressing through it.The New Game+ is the finest example of this mode that I've ever seen. It's not just another run through the campaign at higher difficulty, it actually adds side quests, wonderfully-written journal entries and other bonus to make it well worth playing through again.In short, I highly recommend this game. It's one of the best I've ever played.

Posted: May 20, 2014
												Oddly one of my favorite games that I continue to go back to.  There is no mindblowing gameplay or jawdropping graphics.  What it does it does small scale, but it delights in in each area.Story:  A very solemn themed game about war, sacrifices, dark gods, etc.  Fortunately the main cast have great (sometimes insane)  personalities and have wonderful, surprising, and often hysterical interactions.  This is where the writing really shines and is honestly probably the strongest part of the game.Gameplay:  It's pretty standard tower defense.  Each class has skills, attack range, hit points, etc.  Set them up in likely positions and away you go.  Fail?  Try a different set up.  Characters also level up with experience for new skills, high attack, so forth.  Getting too easy? There's a Newgame+ with harder enemies and achievements that will test you.Graphics:  During gameplay it is high quality pixel art style, detailed and well done.  Cut scenes before and after battles are...I'm not sure what to call it.  Cell shaded stop motion?  It's nice and it does the trick without being flashy.Like I said, I just keep coming back for more, figured I might as well review it.  If you like tower defense games with interesting stories and well written characters, get this.

Posted: February 7, 2015
												From indie developer Level Up Labs, Defenders Quest is a Tower Defence game set in the fantasy world of the Ash Kingdom. Hailing to the final fantasy tactics series with its strategic character placement and pixel art sprites. The unique blend of tactical RPG and Tower defence mechanics offers something familiar but fresh. With a fully customisable cast of characters and intricate levelling system, Defenders Quest is a western effort to try reinvent a diluted genre.You play as the heroine Azra, the former royal librarian of the Ash Kingdom who is exiled to the ruinous outskirts of the city when found dying from the plague. On the brink of death, Azra awakens in a purgatory state to be attacked by a swarm of zombie like creatures or 'Revenant', and by using newly acquired magic and the assistance of a fellow surviving berserk mercenary – you journey through the Pit to uncover the secrets of these creatures and the valley. As you progress you accumulate a small army of companions of different class from swordsman, archers and dragons to face off against a number of tyrants to free the land from the plague. The game primarily revolves around a linear story driven campaign that places you in the overworld of the pit. From here you enter battles that charge waves of enemies at you from designated points, trying to reach and attack Azra. To defeat each wave you tactically place your available units across the map using your Psi resource to do so. Each unit has unique abilities and resistances to overcome each wave. You can also recall and reposition each unit, but this consumes further Psi. Azra also has a host of abilities that can boost her own units and fend off the waves of enemies. Each battle has 3 levels of difficulty and as you progress on normal you can revisit a previous battle to gain further XP and stars.The Overworld also acts as a hub for towns and lairs. Before battles you can visit these locations to recruit units or purchase more effective weapons and armour. You can also complete bonus levels that offer intense challenges for greater reward after gaining enough stars. Defenders Quest is highly accessible but introduces a depth to tower defence that elevates it requiring the player to strategize and carefully consider how each unit is levelled and their positioning in battle. The character development is clearly influenced by role playing games, whilst removing the repetition and time associated with grinding. This effectively ensures your steady progression through the story whilst each battle holds new challenges.The narrative is also highly original and maintains intrigue and invention that is expected of a good RPG. Azra is the sympathetic protagonist facing off against an unknown villainy. The ability to pause a battle at any time emphasises the necessity to properly prepare your units placing them in the most effective positions and levelling them appropriate to the incoming enemies.The game aesthetic is very nostalgic, calling back to the pixel art of classic JRPGs such as Final Fantasy and Chrono Trigger. Each recruit can also have a custom name and colours, allowing you to personalise your army.The main campaign is appropriately paced across seven acts, but encourages you to revisit past levels for bonus equipment and increased challenge. You can complete your army with any class of your choice as their unlocked, further increasing the range of tactics when battling and tailoring your strategies the units you've selected. The breadth and uniqueness of the story is commendable and gives engrossing context to the battles. However the static cut-scenes through which its told at times become unnecessarily prolonged and tedious, after the initial character introductions we generally skipped through them to get to the battles. Furthermore there is a distinct characterised design to the figures in these scenes which drastically differs to the more befitting pixel models. This lack of consistency is also noticeable against the painterly backdrops.Defenders Quest is strongly reminiscent of its influences, but also tries to introduce a more detailed textured interpretation of its characters, that unfortunately leaves to big a void in the games overall presentation.What starts out as a charming and casual game soon evolves into a challenge. Unlike most tower defence games there is no such thing as the ultimate deployment to beat every level. Each battle requires a unique strategy, that sometimes requires you to fine tune each unit. Whilst tower defence remains primarily a casual genre, Level up Labs have crafted a game with a refined battle system and immersive world that requires a fair investment of the players time. Through adapting existing RPG conventions and introducing a few new parameters, Defenders Quest's perilous journey is worthy of the most battle-hardened players.Watch at:

Posted: February 2, 2015
												Defender's quest is a mix of a tower defense + rpg elements and the result is a very addictive game.You're Azra royal librarian casted into the pit because you got the plague, but for some reason you get a strange vision about a golden man and discover new powers capable of destroying revenants for good, now gathering new allies you on a search trying to get out of the pit for your freedom, but also learning why you're special.During the game you will unlock a total of 6 classes of heroes each with different pros and cons, archers low dmg but great range, knight high dmg but slow attack speed, berserker high attack speed medium dmg, ice priest area attacks with crow control skills, priest healer and buffer and dragons overally awesome.There's a total of 30 levels each can be replayed on higher difficulties for more rewards (xp or unique gear for your defenders) but doing higher difficulties requires higher leveled defenders so they can unlock/upgrade skills and passives, unlike other TD games you upgrade the hero to give him a bonus in all stats and unlock his following active skill, which requires previously to level them up outside, kind of confusing but easy to understand as soon as you can see it.There's a set of really hard achievements such as get 180 gold stars without buying generic heroes, reaching wave 100 on endless challenge, and killing a extremely overpowered sheep.Once you beat the game newgame+ gets unlocked, tougher waves, newer gear, 7 side quests which some of them add a lot to the plot, journal logs after every level for more detailed lore about Azra's thoughs about everything than been happening, and items to upgrade the unique gear obtained from doing 3 star levels in normal play, can switch back and forth between both styles at will.Highly recommended even at full price, good TD system and interesting storyline with some (a lot) of funny scenes, i even played 4 hours on a row without even realizing.

Posted: June 21, 2014
												Once you've played one or two tower defenses, you've played them all, right? YES. Well, almost completely yes.I hate this genre with a passion. I enjoyed those first one or two tower defenses I've played, and I'm consistently disappointed with every successive iteration that there is basically no variation whatsoever, especially given how crowded the genre has been. I think it's to do with tower defenses being easy to make, in terms of design, programming, and graphics, so that a lamentably successful game can be made on a dime.However, I do have to give this one game a recommendation. As much as I dislike the genre, this one definitely feels fresher. It blends significant RPG elements into the usual formula. Firstly, it has an engaging story, with plenty of humour and quirky characters. The levels support the story, including the occasional boss fight. Your "towers" are in fact your party members, belonging to six classes, who gain experience from encounters and level up to gain additional skills, or hone their own skills further. This allows for plenty of variation amongst your party, although I found myself sticking to a single formula for each of my types.The gameplay itself is not typical of tower defense. There's no placing your people so that they block enemies; they must be placed on the sidelines of a preset path. Also, there isn't an emphasis on placing more and more towers to increase the length of the gauntlet. Although you can place all 36 members of your party in a level, doing so is generally not recommended, because it is far more efficient to simply upgrade the party members you have. The end result is a far more sparse tower defense game, one that greatly favours tactical placement, and consequently, can be fun for the most jaded tower defense anti-fan.I also appreciated the difficulty system, whereby you can choose from three difficulty settings when playing each level (and a fourth that doesn't exactly count, for casual gamers). You can also come back and play the level on a higher difficulty setting, with different enemy types and levels, to get greater rewards (like unique items). It really added to the longevity of the game. Add in some challenges to complete, and you well and truly get your $15 worth.So, for the first time, I have played a tower defense that has left me wanting more! I'm keeping an eye out on Defender's Quest 2, which is currently in development. If you too are as jaded as I am, don't instantly discount this one. Give the demo a try.

Posted: July 4, 2016
												Defender's Quest: Valley of the Forgotten is an RPG/Tower Defense hybrid. At first, wasn't sure how well the genres would mix. Now, I can say they mix well, at least for this game. It reminds me a lot of Shining Force meets tower defense with realtime combat. The storyline is great, and not overbearing. I enjoyed reading the cutscenes quite a bit. Good sense of humor put into the game as well. I have not beat it yet, so this is based on what I have seen a few hours in.Positives- Great writing/story. Enough character development to understand the story and the role you play in it. At the same time, not necessary if you just want to skip to the tower defense part (though it is worth reading, I assure you).- Decent variety of tower/class types to choose from. You can choose if you want to specialize in a particular type of defender rather than being forced to use them all. Like most tower defense games, you will want some variety though.- Many quality of life features such as individual settings to save for each defender, prompts asking if you want to place defenders in the same place as last time when repeating a map, quick sell options when upgrading equipment, dialogue skip buttons, and many more. The developers were very considerate of our time to include efficient options.- Good replay value. Can go back to the maps you have done before to grind or to try a more challenging version for better rewards.- Well composed music. The music assets are very fitting and relaxing. A great addition to an already entertaining game.- Very robust controls. Clear usable keyboard shortcuts for almost all functions. Many different time controls to slow down or speed up combat to a pace you are comfortable with. And of course, with the ability to pause.- Permanent gear and skill upgrades for the defenders. As opposed to many tower defense games, there are progression elements that will stick with your defenders between maps. Buying/earning better weapons that will stay with your defender until you upgrade helps this feel more RPGish. Skills can be retrained for a reasonable cost of in game coin.Negatives (To be honest, there are not many negative points for this game in my opinion)- Lacking in character customization. While I realize the game is telling a story, I would have liked the ability to choose the gender of the main character. Perhaps if the campaign is completed, there will be something after that for the end game. Not sure.- On the matter of customization, I would have liked to do more than just change the colors of the defenders. Hair styles, a few different faces, nothing major.- Not enough variety in character drawings. This one is a bit nit-picky, but I am struggling to find complaints :p The only time you really see the character drawings in a form that matters is in the cutscenes. The problem with that is the same stances and reaction drawings are recycled throughout the game. I would have liked to see a bit more unique drawings for varying situations.- While the music is a great asset to the game, it does not repeat or transition cleanly in some cases.- Some of the skill progressions at low level seem a little lackluster. For example, a 2% chance to bleed targets per hit feels a bit useless when many of these things die relatively quick. I would prefer either high chance or guaranteed trigger with low or weakened effects to balance it. Granted, I am sure these abilities work well on bosses and larger enemies.TL;DRA great game with a mix of RPG and Tower Defense elements. Excellent musical scores, and a good storyline to boot. Well worth picking up at full price or on sale. I highly recommend this game.

Posted: May 5, 2015
												Verdict: A wonderful take on the often stale Tower Defence genre, with light RPG elements, solid gameplay, excellent art and soundtrack and a simple but endearing story. 8/10Story: The story is simple and humour-orientated, but endearing and, at times, surprisingly engaging given that is delivered through static art cut-scenes and text speech bubbles. The characters are distinctive, fun and memorable. 7/10Gameplay:  The gameplay is solid Tower Defence with light RPG elements. You equip and level up your heroes, which you place as towers to fight off the waves of encroaching enemies. Placement is key, such as placing your ice mages a good distance from your fire-breathing dragons as their abilities will counteract one another, or ensuring your knights will be able to shatter the enemy armour before your archers rain down their arrows for maximum impact. 9/10Graphics: Simple, pixelated graphics are stylistic and get the job done but have been done better elsewhere. Sprites look good, environments are dull and a bit repetitive. The cut-scene art is fantastic. 6/10Sound/Music: The sound effects are basic and appropriate to the pixelated presentation. The soundtrack, on the other hand, is superb. 8/10

content:
Posted: February 9, 2014
												This game mixes the Tower Defense genre with RPG elements.The gameplay is like a normal Tower defense: you must protect something from the enemies that comes from some paths. The  "towers" are berserkes, archers, dragons and more. You get the first new unit for free, which is a character that interfieres in the story, and then you can recruit more. Each character has his own level, and with levels you can teach him more skills. You can (and should) also buy them equipment.Ingame you can level up these units so they can do more damage and use more skills. Your main character can use spells to help your units, so you can attack enemies actively, heal the allies, etc. All of this is not free, of course you need resources.I can't talk too much about story because I'm skipping most of the dialogs, but it is not crap. The characters are good (one of them, Slak, is a ♥♥♥♥ing god).The difficulty... well, I can't say too much, because if you get stuck on one level you can beat previous levels on a higher difficulty level to level up your characters.I really recommend this game to people who like tower defenses.

content:
Posted: July 27, 2016
												This is a great game within its genre. It's an atypical tower defense game with a cute story that's interesting enough to keep you playing. Although the gameplay itself does that sufficiently enough, it's a good addition to a genre that usually lacks such features. Your 'towers' are people and due to it having a story, some of these characters have a personality and that makes it a lot of fun. You can level your towers and have them learn new skills as well as equip them with better weaponry. The game initially isn't hard, but the option to make it so is available for those longing for a challenge. All in all, if you enjoy tower defense games but are looking for something new, I'd say you can't go wrong with this game.If you're not into tower defense games, you might still want to give this game a try as it does certain things common amongst games of its genre differently, and that might just be enough for you. I had a lot of fun with this game and picked it up rather cheaply, for having put over 20 hours in this game I cannot do anything but recommend it at this point. I am looking forward to Defender's Quest 2, it's coming people!

Posted: November 14, 2014
												At first glance, this is a decent TD.Each map has dificulty scaling from brain-dead-easy to challenging-enough-to-keep-you-on-your-toes all the way to so-hard-you-will-have-to-come-back-once-you-have-leveled-up-more.The story is more engaging than many RPGs and shows great humor.The achievements are a decent mix of "collect as you go" and "work hard to get this".The upgrading and customization of your "towers" adds a lot of strategic depth which is only hightened by the weapons and armor you buy/upgrade.And then you finish the game and find out that there are achievements to play with just the story dependant heroes (Hero Mode). And the challenge increases by a factor of 7.And then you finish the game doing Hero Mode and find out about New Game +That's where the game really shines. Because not only is there a whole lot more story, greater challenge in all the previous maps, more achievements AND extra maps... there is also Hero Mode +And then there are all the bonus maps...The game is bursting with content, oozing challenge out of every pixel and spurting out humor.No. Don't wait for a sale. This is not a game you MIGHT want, it is a game you can't NOT have.PS: There is also a sequel coming. Oh, and a free HD version for everyone who has the game.These are the kinds of devs you support. Do it.

content:
Posted: April 25, 2015
												This is a tower defense/RPG hybrid where your towers and home base are all characters that level up between battles, giving you points to spend on stats and extra abilities. No tower mazing is involved, and there are enemies that can attack your towers, necessitating armor, dodge, and healing abilities in addition to strong damage output, slowing attacks, buffs, debuffs, and knockback. Defender's Quest succeeds in blending tower defense and RPG gameplay thanks to strong design on many levels.pros:+ core gameplay is fun -- character and enemy design are good and placing/upgrading your characters always feels strategic+ excellent balance and tuning with multiple difficulty settings+ the interface is intuitive and well-designed+ there is a good amount of content in the game+ graphics may not be fancy, but they're attractive enough and nothing is an eyesore+ good soundtrack and SFX, although more length and variety in level music would be nice+ somewhat engaging but not overly distracting story with effective world-buildingcons:- weak customization: although there are many global spells and character upgrades to choose from, there's rarely more than one viable choice for top effectiveness.- the comedy in the game, while quite funny in its own right, is very silly and can clash with the dramatic aspects of the writing, hurting immersion and undercutting character development (looking at you Slak)Overall, this game is a real gem and I highly recommend it.

content:
Posted: February 22, 2015
												I usually prefer to wait until I finish a game before I review it (barring episodic games but even then I finish the episodes that are available THEN review) but I enjoyed this game so much I figured I'd might as well review even before I finished it -- especially since it seems like there's so much to do! First of all, I'm not normally a tower defense fan; I actually picked up Defender's Quest as part of a Humble Bundle female protagonists deal. I don't even remember why I decided to try the game on a whim but I'm SO glad I did. The story is interesting and, even better, funny. There's tons of really good characters and the devs have done a good job of creating a story that walks the line between silly and serious pretty well. In terms of the gameplay, like I said -- I don't particularly enjoy tower defense, mostly because the ones I've played previous to this have all seemed far too complicated to be worth the time and effort. Prior to Defender's Quest, the game that I've enjoyed the most in the genre was Plants vs. Zombies. Defender's Quest is a step above that, really, because DQ actually attempts to have a story and character development, though the basic goals of the two games are the same. I'd say DQ is a little bit tougher than PvZ, if only because there's a lot more variability in the maps, whereas PvQ was a fairly straight-forward flat plain. DQ offers maps with multiple enemy spawn points (three is the most I've seen so far), different terrain (e.g., water vs. land), and various restrictions in routes for enemies (and placement for allies). I especially enjoyed the way you can change battle speed to slow down -- or pause -- the enemies spawning to catch up or speed up (4X is amazing) if you're sure your allies can handle the enemies without much management. It's a nice mix that I liked, because I prefer to micro-manage at the start, rather than during the battle. Even better is the different battle difficulty settings, so you can go back and replay battles on a harder setting (same map, different enemies) PLUS bonus challenges and (so the achievements would suggest) a new game plus mode -- means there's tons of stuff to do. Playing DQ actually makes me want to go out and find similar tower  defense games to play because I enjoyed this one so much -- which is probably the best compliment I can give a game!

												An excellent tower defense game that's very fun to play. The story is engrossing and well written and it has a nice difficulty curve. It also sports the best new game + modes I've ever played. I plan to buy the sequel to this day 1, and I plan to play the awesome free HD update that this game is getting from beggining to end. I'm hard pressed to think of any part about this game I didn't like. It can be a bit grindy but that's only if you decide you want to try to beat all of the difficulties in 1 sitting. For those of you who like to slap a game into hardmode from the getgo I guess I'd advise you to stay away because hard mode will kick you in the nuts, light you on fire, and then throw you out the window unless your characters are ready for it.Great game from an awesome indie dev team. Well worth your time and money.

DFQ2 is in the works, and they're working on re-releasing DFQ1 on the same engine that #2's gonna be on, BUT IN GLORIOUS HD. also this game features a female lead, really cool post-apocalyptic/plague-time setting, has TONS of silliness and laughs yet manages not to downplay the really uncool villainous stuff for comedic effect. Definitely recommmend!

number of helpful: 2 of 3 people (67%) found this review helpful1 person found this review funny
content:
Posted: January 8, 2015
												Tower defense meets RPG.  Somehow it works really, really well.Worth noting that I usually hate tower defense games.  I think I got this as part of a Humble Bundle or something and only installed it when I was really bored one night and suffering from insomnia.  It made my night a whole lot better.  Characters of different classes replace what would normally be different defense turrets in other games, but you level them up individually with a skill tree unique to each class.  These unlocked skills and stats stay between maps, so you might have one archer set up for fantastic range while you set another one up for massive damage and a third for rate of fire.  This keeps the game interesting.  Also, none of the maps feel impossible to achieve a perfect on, as long as you're strategic and patient.  There's also a New Game + mode.  In retrospect, I'd be willing to have spent full price on this.EDIT:I went back and played through this game over the last couple of weeks and realized how good of a story it has.  The game manages to mix serious and humorous very well.  The writing is better than most games that cost five times as much.  I even pre-purchased the sequel directly from the developer because of how much I enjoyed this game.

content:
Posted: May 11, 2014
												This game is quite a treat. I love its art style and combat mechanics. Its a refreashing take on the Tower defense genre with some fun rpg elements mixed in. You name you heros, level them, and find new equipment for them. Then these heros are used in a tower defense acting in place of the towers. The combat is like Final Fantasy Crystal Defenders.The conversations are quite amusing and the story thus far has been pretty entertaining and is keeping me hooked and wanting to learn more. I also love puns so this game gets points there.There are two big complaints I have for the title though. The biggest is that you have to run it at a fixed resolution in windowed mode. The window is so small it could very well fit on an 8" tablet. This means playing for an extended period will likely hurt your eyes. I really wish I could make the game bigger without having to use fullscreen. The second complaint is the sound. It gets very bad when you have a healer and ice hero on the field. Especially a 4x speed. I would recommend turning the sound off and either listening to the in game music or playing your own. There is not voice acting so you wont be missing anything.

content:
Posted: March 19, 2014
												I bought this one because I remember playing it as a website's free flash game and I had very good memories of it. This game makes a perfect mix between Tower Defense (something I love) and RPG (which is a 'meh' to me). Defender's Quest may look like a 10 minutes casual game but it's not. It has an incredibly long story and it's full of challenges. You have a great control over difficulty in this game as each stage has 4 levels of difficulty, which also makes this game very replayable, as you'll need future gained strength to beat the 4th level of past stages.Despite of my lack of interest in RPG, the mix with Tower Defense is so good and balanced that I really enjoyed that part. You can have your very own and custom gameplay, as you plan your own team, choose how they evolve and choose the gear they equip.Defender's Quest is a great tactical game, it gives you a lot of freedom to test different strategies and it can give you different gameplay experiences based on your own choices and it doesn't get repetitive, something that is easily found in any other Tower Defense game.Gonchito approves this! (Yeah, I'm so great that I speak about me in third person).

content:
Posted: June 13, 2016
												Here it is almost 4 years later and we're about to get a HD remake and then the sequel. This game still holds up as one of the best tower defense games of all time. It's got RPG elements like leveling, skills and equipment alongside an engaging and entertaining story. There's plenty of depth and content and with the upcoming HD remake I'm looking forward to playing through it all over again. The graphics still look alright despite the age, there's a certain charm to the cutscenes and art style in general. This is going to change once the HD remake comes out but it will still be there as an option for those who want it. The music's good and everything in general is really good. There are a multitude of difficulty customization options and even challenges for achievements or in game rewards, such as never hiring anyone and running through the game with only the story characters (which is really hard) and then running through it again on New Game+ with these same people and getting all the levels beaten on all difficulties (which is almost impossible). There's so many strategies and options available that you will be playing this many many times.

												If you love tower defence game, you will not regret picking this one up. content:
Posted: January 17, 2014
												This is a great tower defense game with lots or RPG elements included.  Instead of towers, you have heroes you position along a path to defend your leader.  As these heroes fight, they level up and can be built into different styles of tower depending on the skills you take.Pros- Lots of good tower defense gameplay- Lots of well done RPG elements so you can modify each hero and personalize your play style- Good story and interesting characters- Lots of great items to equip to make your heroes (towers) even more effective- The game rewards replay of older levels on higher difficulties by giving your heroes (towers) more experience and the ability to unlock special items- Lots of replay value with all the difficulty levels and all the things that can be unlocked.- Challenging maps that sometimes require you to think outside your normal setups.Cons- Older graphics- Gameplay can be repetative if you're just interested in the storyOverall this is a great game that I would highly recommend to an RPG or tower defense enthusiast. The game gives you the option of both relaxed gameplay and very challening maps if you want them.  (It also rewards your party for completing said maps.)

Game wants you to play it, not get stuck in place for weeks on end.Top 3 of its genre, guaranteed, and I only say top 3 because I know some people disagree with me on what the other two'd be. (for what it's worth I put this above Defense Grid, but I thought Defense Grid blew compared to Sol Survivor and its multiplayer).

content:
Posted: December 4, 2013
												this game has bad artthe rest is AWESOME. story is good. gameplay is solid. if i were to describe the gameplay its something like an rpg, except the combat has been replaced by tower-defence. each character you meet that joins your army can be placed down on the map, then it will attack with whichever move is off cooldown at the time. it speaks for itself that you have to place these "towers" in an tactical superior way, so they help each other kill the revenants (zombie type mobs with a variety of mechanics such as, but not limited to, attacking back, being able to swim,..).RPG:despite this being part rpg this does not contain any "choice" as regards to storyline (except maybe 1, though its very clear which one is superior). you do get to pick traits out of trait trees and make every character unique in its fighting style. also you can equip all your characters with weapons and armor (except the last kind, though you will understand when you get there). different weapons do no have different boons, the more expensive ones simply do more damage. same goes for armor, the more money it costs the more defense it gives. the customizability is in the trait system, definitely not the equipment system.tower defense:each tower is unique, and at the end of every match you get xp and perhaps a trait point (lvl up) to decide how you want to build it. you can improve your tower during the match though, with the match currency called spi, this will give him/her access to more moves. you can not block paths, or build any kind of obstruction to make the mobs change course. this is one of the tower defense mechanics that is missing (can't have it all).overall i would have gladly payed the full price for this game. it took me 20 hours to finish one playthrough 100%, and a short dabble in the new game+ feature. that is less then 1 euro per hour.played it on a windows 7 ultimate laptop, 3.3Ghz, 8GB ram, 3GB nvidia gpu with only 2 crashes, and very rarely some fps drop.

number of helpful: 2 of 3 people (67%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: December 27, 2013
												An original approach to story design and a nice take on tower defense, Defender's Quest places you in the role of Azra, a librarian who gets epic powers to fight the otherwise invulnerable undead.The story has been designed from the ground up: taking the game mechanics of upgradable towers who gain experience to become stronger ("like an RPG"), a story to fit the mechanics has been devised. Quite like when you were presented with the task of making up a story and including certain words or characters, only Level Up Labs made a game out of that. The benefit is mostly avoiding pitfalls growing out of weird game mechanics. IMHO, while the story did not blow my mind it is still very fine and the result works quite well.So, like any tower defense, you defend a place from creeps that have different stats and abilities by placing "towers". In this they're game characters who have their own class and the associated, developable skills, i.e. attacks, buffs and debuffs. Azra summons them up and places them into the labyrinth in suitable locations. Every character is useful and has their role: to spell it out no one works as an instakill device against everything. The enemies always follow shortest path towards Azra, so you can plan accordingly even when some enemies can swim. Finally, if the troops fail, you can beat the horde back with spells. Everything uses kills for money.On the world map, you move along a linear path that sometimes diverges for sidequests. Every space is either a level with attacking waves of enemies or a town where you can buy weapons and armor and recruit troops. Story advances in every space so you're never bored unless getting stuck in a difficult level. That does not happen often, for the easy levels are really easy and you can even go to casual difficulty and/or set experience and money gain to 3x normal for faster leveling up without any penalty. You do get better rewards for higher difficulties, and to master a level it has to be beaten on extreme: this always rewards you with a special item granting the incentive for beating them all, if the associated achievement won't do it alone. You can also return to beat the levels again after you've grown in strength.When the levels run out, there are several "challenge" levels to beat, two of which are of endless type with ever-so stronger incoming waves. After beating the game you can also give it another go with NG+ that is more difficult with monsters getting additional special abilities. NG+ also adds several additional sidequests and its own version of the challenges.While the flash graphics aren't eye candy, the music is engaging and the residing mechanics will let you enjoy the game for several tens of hours. However, trying to beat every level perfectly can become tedious, for the levels get tougher and tougher as you advance. Typing this, I've yet to beat the last few levels on extreme. Still, I would heartily recommend the game for tower defense fans: I sure got a blast with it. I especially recommend going for the Hero Mode+ challenge (and to lesser extent the Hero Mode++).

content:
Posted: June 22, 2016
												This game was amazing back when I first got it for cheap cheap from a Steam coupon. I saw it was a tower defense game, and I said to myself, "This is only a few bucks, I'll try it out." Oh my, I didn't know how much I would love this game.Defender's Quest is a tower defense game with RPG elements, mainly experience points, skill trees, and a good story inbetween the gameplay. It the game has humor, which is rather welcome. The gameplay is where this game really shines.This is simply the best tower defense game I've ever played. You may have played a tower defense game before, but you haven't played Defender's Quest. It has a lot of depth to its gameplay, it has a very intuitive UI and an unobtrusive tutorial that is very helpful. Tutorial can be turned off entirely in the options, if you really want to. While you're at it, you can increase the experience and gold you get from the game to make it easier, or crash it into the ground and make the game harder. The music fits the game's atmosphere perfectly. I haven't even mentioned that you can mod every aspect of this game yet. Go look in the workshop; the creators of the game made a free sci-fi version of the game just to show you how much flexibility there is in regular modding.Everything I've mentioned was made better with the recent update. I recommend this game wholeheartedly. 10/10.

content:
Posted: January 7, 2016
												I forgot I had this game and I am ashamed that I forgot I had it. I had a lot of fun playing this before, as I did just now, but it is late. I feel it deserves my thumbs up. I'll tell ya why.You are a lady who finds people to join you and help out as the story progresses. The story is quite nice. The people are funny and will often make jokes and claim that they hate the hero, when really they don't.The actual gameplay itself is typical of most tower defense. You have a grid where you place your units (the 'people' that joined you), and they fight when something is near. What I like about this game is that the different types of units work together. I won't go into any detail about this because you'll probably want to experience it yourself.Each level is split up into four difficulties. So if you're feeling brave, you can try the hardest. Even if you fail your units will still gain experience points. If you're feeling like a wuss, try the casual setting.The units have skill trees which you apply 1 point on each level up. I find this to be very rewarding, although sometimes when you complete a level you may have to apply a buncha points (I had to apply about 20 before after one level). C'est la vie.It is well worth the whatever I paid for it. I don't remember buying it, but I am very glad I did. You'll not be disappointed if you're a fan of tower defense games with a hint of humour and a nice storyline.

number of helpful: 3 of 5 people (60%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: November 27, 2013
												Never thought RPG and Tower defence genre could have a great cross-bred like this!Like any other TD games out there, your main mission is prevent any enimies from reaching the party leader standing at the end of the road. The horde which is consist of a few types of zombies, slug-like creatures,... keeps coming in pre-defined routes. In fact, there's nothing quite unique in the mechanic of TD in this game.However, the true gem lies in the RPG aspect of the game. What's a TD game without towers? Nah, your towers now are replaced by class-based characters ranging from a psychopath to a cute dragon. Many elements of RPG genre are brought into the game like skill tree, equipments and again, classes. Trouble with fast moving creeps, you have an Ice Mage to counter, or facing heavy armor zombies with the might of a Paladin.Not every maps are so hard, but you still need to grind a little for exp and especially epic items. (well, not really that epic but atleast they have purple titles)To be honest, you can't expect a long and heart-touching story with dozens of play time for such a small game like this, but for almost 3 hours so far I'm quite satisfied. Finally, thanks jatan11t/GAR for this lovely gift :)

content:
Posted: November 8, 2013
												This is a super addictive tower defense game.  Take on the role of a Librarian who is thought to contract the plague and tossed into "the pit" a canyon seperated from the rest of civilization where plague victims spend the rest of their days.  She takes on a mysterious power that allowes her and people she connects to mentally the ability to completely destroy the undead revenant that the plague victims become.  Like other tower defense games you need to protect the goal from hordes of invading enemies with units or towers that you place along the pathways to destroy the enemies.  However, unlike other games, this one has a story, and your characters stay with you, level up and grow along side your main unit.  This game comes complete with mod support from the devs so that you can change things in a seperate module as you like if you want a more/less challenging playthrough, as well as letting you change character designs and spell effects. 8/10 will play again.

content:
Posted: January 25, 2014
												This game is a brilliant tower defense game. You take a very active role in upgrading towers/people and using active powers. There is a robust upgrade system for your hero and each type of tower/role. The game has an EXCELLENT story with unusually distinct and interesting characters. As for longevity, there is a new game+ mode that adds new side quests involving a completely new story line! There is plenty of incentive to go back and replay levels at harder difficulties because the rewards are improved and there are different enemies, which can drastically change how a level plays. Seriously, this game is great value at full price and a steal if you ever see it on sale. If you like this genre, just buy it already!

number of helpful: 1 of 2 people (50%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: January 25, 2014
												I know there are a ton of tower defense games out there... and even a few that propose to add RPG-like elements.  Defender's quest is different, and different good.  The game strikes that perfect balance by replacing the "towers" with NPCs.  The difficulty ramp-up is near perfect for a game and gives you as much challenge as you want without subjecting you to any levels where you fall off a difficulty cliff.  If something's just a little too hard, or you're trying to get a better result?  Level up your guys or buy them beter equipment.Yes, the game runs at a fixed resolution and no, the cutscenes (which tell an engrossing tale) are done with limited animation, but that's really OK.   The limitations don't detract from the game and you can tell all of the love and time and effort went into perfecting gameplay and giving you plenty of it.  If you're lukewarm on tower defense because you don't like the repetition, this game's for you.  If you're a die-hard TD fanatic, this game's for you.  Accessible, perfect ramp-up, plenty of content, and a story.  Definitely this game is one to get.

content:
Posted: April 6, 2014
												Don't be turned off by the graphics of this game.  It really is something special.  It's lane defense, pure and simple, but it does this so well, making it an rpg where all your towers can level up and improve through skill trees unique to them.  The graphics are a bit primitive, and the story cut scenes might turn some people off, but give it a chance.  The story is what sold me, as it's incredibly funny without having to go through the self aware brand of humor.  It's just really well written, with great jokes and comedic timing.  The gameplay is very satisfying and there's a lot of things to do, thanks to new game plus and challenge modes.  You can even tweak how fast your characters level in order to speed your game along.  I cannot recommend this enough because it's just fun and gives you so many options for play.  There's even an option to increase game speed to make those usually slow lane defense games super fast, for either convenience or increased difficulty.  Wonderful little title.

												A great game from this publisher!  You are given heroes that you can upgrade that act as your towers and each set of heroes has a skill tree that you can perosonalize to a certain degree. number of helpful: 1 of 2 people (50%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: June 21, 2015
												Pros+ Fun tower defense game with great gameplay+ Can adjust difficulty+ Amusing dialogue+ Can customize units+ New game + adds new features that provide replay valueCons- Graphics are unimpressive- Music is repetitive- Cut scenes look like they were made in MS Paint- If you want the achievements, you can't utilize the unit customizationOverall score: 8/10Defender's Quest is a great tower defense game for fans of the genre. It is the only tower defense game I can think of that has a decent plot, which I think adds to the game's charm. You can also adjust the game's difficulty without any penalty. (300% gold and EXP is very useful when you need to grind.) I also like how I can name and customize my units. So many tower defense games have you fill the screen with identical units, so it's nice to create an army of unique people.I'm not very picky when it comes to graphics, but I think the game could really use better graphics and music. It's not a deal-breaker, but it does take away from game to some extent. Also, I like playing for achievements, but some of the game's achievements prevent you from using one of using one of the game's best features; namely, you can't utilize the unit customization since recruitable units are not Hero Units. I think that's a disappointment, but this is only a problem if you actually care about achievements.Overall, Defender's Quest is a fun tower defense game that has lots of charm. If you enjoy tower defense games, I'd definitely recommend Defender's Quest for some classic tower defense gameplay.

number of helpful: 2 of 4 people (50%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: November 9, 2015
												I wrote a review for this about a year or so ago but thought I'd rewrite it as I have some different and new views on the game.First off, this is a tower defense game that revolves around a well written story with a nicely done narrative that includes all the who/what/when/where/why questions, along with moments of subtle humor and despair. On the first play through you get all the character dialogue that propels the story but not a whole lot more. On the second play through you get the main character's (Azra unless otherwise named) thoughts after each mission is completed. These journal entries go pretty in-depth for being subtext you don't even need to go through. There are some 30 entries and I do recommend reading them.The game starts with the Azra wondering where the hell she is and finding the first warrior, Slak, entering into a battle against the Revenant (the dead). The story progresses and you will find all the other characters (read 'towers'). There are six others you find and you can have up to six of them in that class, in total allowing you to have an army of 36 towers and Azra.The Berserker is a hack 'n' slash guy. He wields a sword, wears no shirt, and thirsts for blood.The Ranger is your snarky and quick witted bow expert. She often griefs Azra on menial things such as, "not being pretty enough to have her plans work out."The Healer comes off as overprotective and cautious but holds the team together.The Ice Mage is cold and has cynical tendencies but wields the power to stop hordes of foes.The Knight is rightous and pledges himself to Azra. He takes down the strongest enemies by ripping them of their armor.The Dragon is the last to join the group. She acts like a god and thinks the humans beneath her yet is impressed at how far Azra and her companions have traveled thus far. She also enjoys eating sheep.With these characters you can create varying strategies on every battlefield in the game. Some will require a near exact positioning that you'll figure out by trial and error, while others are more liberal in placement. You can pull off a ton of combos though and it's cool to find something that synergizes well.Now, along with all the characters, each has a skill branch (not tree since there are only two directions it goes) and with each level you get one point to put in each skill slot. Most of them are damage boosts for their attack tier (each character has a five tier attack that is upgraded through Psi that is earned by killing enemies in the level) and the rest are passive buffs. They can include skill cooldowns, range, crit/poison/bleed/blind/armor piercing chance, slow/stun/burn, group damage amplifiers and tagging enemies so they take more damage.Azra also has six spells she can upgrade. There are three damage and three buff spells. A direct lightning attack, an area of effect crystal explosion, and a full screen flame attack. The buffs are sending your characters into a frenzy to increase attack speed, massive healing, and pushing back waves of enemies. There are also unlockable spell books that can be equipped to provide boosts.There are three weapons in game that two classes can use. Swords for the Berserker and Knight, a bow for the Ranger, and staffs for the Healer and Ice Mage. Progressing through the story increases the price and damage of future weapons. Armor can be equipped to them as well, heavy and light variants. The max level each member can achieve is 60 so you won't be able to max every skill on each character. The good thing about having multiple in a class means that you can have someone with a high bleed chance, and give the other person the higher armor piercing chance. At any point you can pay a small fee of scrap (currency) to respec their builds.So that's the gist of the game. Pretty straight forward. Where things really get rolling are on the new game +. Much more challenging and rewarding. A new currency of "skulls" becomes used to upgrade the special weapons and armors you aquire through missions. It's pretty hard to get all the skulls as you'll need to grind to get your characters to a high enough level to beat the much harder than before levels. There are also a few puzzles hidden here and there that you need to keep an eye out for. I had some trouble with it and found a guide and without it there would've never been a way I'd have caught on.All in all, more than your run of the mill tower defense game, great story, fun and unique characters, scaling rewards that only get better and better through all the challenges, and tons of replayability as there is mod support. Oh, if you really want a challenge, there's an achievement to beat the game and new game + with only the original characters, not using any of the extra hired ones. And then getting 180 stars (awarded through level completion). That took a ton of time.

content:
Posted: January 26, 2014
												 I picked it up because it was 90% off....and 3.4 hours later I'm at Act IV, even if for some it may seem repetitive or easy, it's worth it, since the game makes you have to think about positioning and things like that, like most TD games. You can also equip items to your "towers" in order to make them stronger and there are also skills that improve them a lot, which as opposed to just upgrading the "towers" so they do more damage and things like that. I like these kind of games a lot, I would say since back when Warcraft III had that kind of deal going. I am sure there was in Starcraft, but I wasn't able to access B.net at that time. For me the fact that it's an RPG/TD caught my attention, because I like RPGs and well, combining RPG with Tower Defense is no easy deal, right? (Can't say I have experience with something that has both, always have gone for one of the two.)10/10 would recommend.

content:
Posted: January 26, 2014
												DEFENDER'S QUEST: VALLEY OF THE FORGOTTEN is really fun -- especially because you, the gamer, are given a TON of freedom to customize the game that YOU want to play.  This means -- you can play the original game and slowly level up at a normal pace, OR you can turn on the 300% bonus and level up super fast, blasting through your foes and the missions (with no negative consequences to the story or achievements). The ACHIEVEMENTS are fun to attain, even more so since you can craft the game that you want.  The TUTORIALS are spot on, easy to follow, and makes the gameplay very quick to learn and execute. The STORY and ILLUSTRATIONS are well done and add a lot to the game's enjoyment and depth. Better still is that DEFENDER'S QUEST is part of the Steam Trading Cards program. Definitely recommended gaming.

content:
Posted: January 25, 2014
												I know there are a ton of tower defense games out there... and even a few that propose to add RPG-like elements.  Defender's quest is different, and different good.  The game strikes that perfect balance by replacing the "towers" with NPCs.  The difficulty ramp-up is near perfect for a game and gives you as much challenge as you want without subjecting you to any levels where you fall off a difficulty cliff.  If something's just a little too hard, or you're trying to get a better result?  Level up your guys or buy them beter equipment.Yes, the game runs at a fixed resolution and no, the cutscenes (which tell an engrossing tale) are done with limited animation, but that's really OK.   The limitations don't detract from the game and you can tell all of the love and time and effort went into perfecting gameplay and giving you plenty of it.  If you're lukewarm on tower defense because you don't like the repetition, this game's for you.  If you're a die-hard TD fanatic, this game's for you.  Accessible, perfect ramp-up, plenty of content, and a story.  Definitely this game is one to get.

												You play as  Azra, a librarian who's been plague-infected and thus thrown into  the Pit. This deep and vast place was supposed to be her graveyard but instead, on the brink of death she learns of her new powers and purpose. Defender's Quest: Valley of the Forgotten  is a tower defense mixed with RPG elements. It features a decent story spiced with funny dialogue between party members (unfortunately not voice acted). It's also worth keeping in mind that the game gets really, really hard towards the end of the ng+ playthrough even with end game gear and abilities.Highly recommended for those who enjoy tower defenses.

Posted: April 6, 2014
												Don't be turned off by the graphics of this game.  It really is something special.  It's lane defense, pure and simple, but it does this so well, making it an rpg where all your towers can level up and improve through skill trees unique to them.  The graphics are a bit primitive, and the story cut scenes might turn some people off, but give it a chance.  The story is what sold me, as it's incredibly funny without having to go through the self aware brand of humor.  It's just really well written, with great jokes and comedic timing.  The gameplay is very satisfying and there's a lot of things to do, thanks to new game plus and challenge modes.  You can even tweak how fast your characters level in order to speed your game along.  I cannot recommend this enough because it's just fun and gives you so many options for play.  There's even an option to increase game speed to make those usually slow lane defense games super fast, for either convenience or increased difficulty.  Wonderful little title.

content:
Posted: January 31, 2014
												As a person who started his TD career in WC2/SC i'd say this is some of the most fun I have had playing a tower defense game. Instead of using Towers you call forth allies to your astral plane (Current Map) to help defend yourself from Revenent's (The bad guys). There are several different Allies to choose from and each ally can be specifically tailored for any given purpose. There is a suprising amount of depth involved in deciding where to place your unused talent points. Each character is Namable and has cosmetic customizable options. Naming a Character after yourself makes you want to use that character which is alot of fun to role play. If your into that sort of thing.The town's have places to recruit new allies and buy new weapon and armor. The map plays out alot like Mario World or the equivalent and you can go back and beat older levels on harder diff's to get better gear and level. There is also a storyline written by some type of Wrinting/English major and the writing isn't too terrible. Some if it will give you a laugh and some will just make you scratch your head. But all in all this game is a lot of fun and is definitely worth the little money asked.-Casey

number of helpful: 1 of 2 people (50%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: November 27, 2013
												Tied in my mind with Defense Grid for best tower-defense game to date. Where Defense Grid's strength is the perfect distillation of the tower-defense formula, Defender's Quest remains toe-to-toe with it because of how it radically adapts the basic idea of tower-defense -- deploying stationary defenses along a path or series of paths -- to work with a highly original fantasy setting and a set of solid RPG-like mechanics. The presentation, while not sophisticated, is incredibly appealing, and the writing is nothing short of superb.  It's also endlessly replayable, and the New Game + mode actually gives you a reason to do so.Highly recommended to everyone, tower-defense fans and non-fans alike.  As with Defense Grid, If you're a fan, you will like this; if you're not already, this stands a good chance of converting you, and if it doesn't, then you never have to wonder about another tower-defense game again, as you'll know it's just not your bag.

												I got this game in a bundle and didn't think much of it at first glance because of the graphics. I started it up just to confirm that I could dismiss it, and four hours later, I came up for air and I realized I was having a blast! Defender's Quest is amazing. Don't dismiss it because of the graphics; the graphics' quality has no bearing on the gameplay. DQ is challenging, amusing, difficult, easy, and rewarding. Great music. Good story. High replayability because it has 34 maps, 4 difficulty levels for all maps, new game+ with all maps, and eight bonus challenges! And it offers some crazy difficult achievements. If you have any interest in tower defense, strategy battles, turn-based combat, indie games, or RPGs, get this game right now. It is one of most fun games I've ever played.

number of helpful: 1 of 3 people (33%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: October 16, 2015
												A fun little tower defense with RPG elements. The protagonist is a librarian cast into a plague colony, and sets out on a quest to escape. She quickly discovers latent supernatural powers that allow others to defeat the zombified infected. She serves as the objective that must be defended. Besides the standard ability to summon units to defend her, she's also capable of casting spells for harming or buffing, and can equip spell books to further enhance her abilities.Throughout the game you'll encounter characters who join with you, unlocking new classes of characters (berserker, archer, healer, etc.) that you can hire and summon to defend you. The classes come with simple skill trees that unlock new abilities or enhance them in some way, and every individual unit can be leveled differently from the other, enabling a more diverse army to choose from.The game is made for a wide variety of skill levels. New players and seasoned veterans alike will find something to challenge them when the game gets rolling, and you can replay maps as you please for practice or for XP/money. The map's rewards are better for higher difficulty settings, and can reward unique equipment for success. The game can seem like a grindfest, but the devs wisely included the option to increase XP/money gains and to ensure all units get equal access to it, regardless of whether or not they entered battle.The story itself is very competent. The characters are largely likeable and the writing and humor is enjoyable. The cast tend to have something of an emphasis on their quirks, but mostly avoid becoming bland one notes with varying degrees of depth.The game is not without its flaws. Completionists can find that the New Game+ might become something of a chore, the skill trees are rather simple in their execution, and certain parts of the story or characters can become tiresome (looking at you, Slak). If you can put this aside, you still have a fun and funny game that's worth a look. Grab the demo and give it a spin. You can even transfer your save file if you choose to purchase it, and the game is set to receive an HD update (at the time of writing) and sequel.

number of helpful: 1 of 3 people (33%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: October 16, 2015
												A fun little tower defense with RPG elements. The protagonist is a librarian cast into a plague colony, and sets out on a quest to escape. She quickly discovers latent supernatural powers that allow others to defeat the zombified infected. She serves as the objective that must be defended. Besides the standard ability to summon units to defend her, she's also capable of casting spells for harming or buffing, and can equip spell books to further enhance her abilities.Throughout the game you'll encounter characters who join with you, unlocking new classes of characters (berserker, archer, healer, etc.) that you can hire and summon to defend you. The classes come with simple skill trees that unlock new abilities or enhance them in some way, and every individual unit can be leveled differently from the other, enabling a more diverse army to choose from.The game is made for a wide variety of skill levels. New players and seasoned veterans alike will find something to challenge them when the game gets rolling, and you can replay maps as you please for practice or for XP/money. The map's rewards are better for higher difficulty settings, and can reward unique equipment for success. The game can seem like a grindfest, but the devs wisely included the option to increase XP/money gains and to ensure all units get equal access to it, regardless of whether or not they entered battle.The story itself is very competent. The characters are largely likeable and the writing and humor is enjoyable. The cast tend to have something of an emphasis on their quirks, but mostly avoid becoming bland one notes with varying degrees of depth.The game is not without its flaws. Completionists can find that the New Game+ might become something of a chore, the skill trees are rather simple in their execution, and certain parts of the story or characters can become tiresome (looking at you, Slak). If you can put this aside, you still have a fun and funny game that's worth a look. Grab the demo and give it a spin. You can even transfer your save file if you choose to purchase it, and the game is set to receive an HD update (at the time of writing) and sequel.

number of helpful: 1 of 3 people (33%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: November 1, 2015
												Edit, update: apparently the graphics will be getting a *free* HD update, which is exactly what I felt was missing with this game. My recomendation is to WAIT for the free HD update before playing. Go ahead and buy it now if it is on sale.Counter review to all the fanboy hype for this game, as I just bought it on sale since it looked good and I needed something to play on my mac book.This is JUST any other tower defense game. Because every tower defence game has its own unique mechanics for upgrades. The only thing this game "blends" is RPG lore/tropes into tower defense as a theme. This is done in that you upgrade individual towers and each tower levels up on its own. That's it. The blend is just graphical, and it does that poorly because the graphics are poorly done. I don't want to be harsh because I want to give the indie devs the benefit of the doubt in that they couldn't aquire funding/talent for aethistics, but this is worse than a free flash game I could have played instead. Another problem which just elludes to really ameature/cheap UI development is that the game cannot go into fullscreen correctly. It just remains at 800x600 and the fullscreen option simply draws a giant black box on your monitor and centers teh 800x600 game. Why couldn't they have actually developed the UI before releasing it...? Not really a pleasing game to play, way better TD games imho. A game like "Castaway Tower Defense" has much better graphics/UI/visual-imersion than this for example and is free.As for the writing, it is cute but not good. Some of it is just wrong regarding vocabulary which is odd since one of the selling points was that it was "actually written by an English Major". For example, one of the bad guys loses his entire army and complains that his forces were decimated. Just bad and confusing writing, as the verb "to decimate" means to reduce by 10%. This is something that the Romans would do to their own troops to instill fear into them, to punish them, and to prevent rebellion. It is not something that would happen if you lose all of your army, that would be to have been obliterated or to annihilate.

content:
Posted: February 17, 2014
												This is easily the best tower defense type of game that I have ever played. The difficulty starts off quite easy and gradually adds new unit types on both offense and defense. The regular game never really gets too tough but once you start up a new game+ the gloves come off and it stops holding your hand altogether. Persistant leveling and a well written comical story seal the deal and really suck you in. Cut scenes are minimalistic but very well done.I bought this game on sale without really knowing anything about it other than it looked cool and was really cheap yet I really wish I had bought it sooner. A lot of indies get a lot of undeserved hype while this one got none that I heard of. Really fun game that everyone should own.
