content:
Posted: February 4, 2014
												Let me start by saying one thing: I don’t like TDs. Too many of them revolve around mechanics I consider boring, such as interest, and generally, they don’t offer much beyond the core, basic gameplay expected from the genre. With that out of the way, I’ll try to explain how Defender’s Quest won me over.It’s impossible not to mention the fantastic writing present in the game: The story is overall serious, but the script makes no commitment to sounding mature or gritty. To the contrary: while some may argue the cast is composed of very standard archetypes, it’s still highly varied, and the humorous exchanges between the characters are a joy to see. Ironically, it’s their likability that makes the story much easier to care about, not presentation or “visceral” experiences. Take notes, games industry.While I’m at it, the soundtrack is also a very strong point, and is included in the game’s folder for free. Plot and music are hardly all the game has to offer, though. As I said, I don’t like TDs and what impresses me the most about Defender’s Quest is how it carefully avoids annoying mechanics I’ve come to associate with the genre.In this game, you don’t have to worry about insane resource management (interest) or fast finger movement (since you can pause mid-wave). It’s only about character loadout and positioning. That doesn’t mean it’s easy, but that it’s the right kind of hard. That it offers depth.Going through the game should take you about five hours, but that can increase tenfold if you try to finish all level variations and challenges. For me, it clocked at just over sixty hours, and was definitely worth its price. I can recommend it to anyone looking for a twist on the traditional TD formula.

number of helpful: 0 of 1 people (0%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: November 28, 2015
												This one is a soft recommendation for meDefender's Quest is an interesting twist on the tower defense paradigm. This time, your "towers", are RPG heroes you're summoning on the battle field. This makes for a much more interesting story, with many characters voicing their opinions on what you're doing (usually to complain about it :p). The story itself isn't revolutionary, but it's servicable.Unfortunately, by making the game an hybrid of TD and RPG, Defender's Quest brings with it the bad aspects of RPG. Mostly, the grind. There will be times where you're facing a level which you simply can't win because your characters/towers aren't levelled up enough. So you will have to grind by doing other stuff (like replaying levels on a harder difficulty) before coming back. It's even more notable and grindy when you're trying to keep your adventuring party small, like the games encourages you to do (by raising recruitement prices, but also having some achievements that only unlock if you never expand your roster).Another problem with the small roster is that in many levels, there are some optimal positions to place your 5 or 6 people, and then you're pretty much done, you fast forward to see your team hacking and slashing away for several minutes until the level is done. There are some levels where you will more active, with your main character having to use its spells, and you having to replace some of your team in better places. But on the whole, it's a rather static tower defense, since you have limited number of people, an enticement to bunch them together (for increased efficiency) and a limited mana pool to summon.All that bad stuff being said, Defender's Quest is still way better than most tower defense. The writing is good, the levels are interesting and you can always stop at any point. The main game is pretty easy to finish, while the main game plus will offer a bigger challenge, but also new items, additional missions and optional quests to keep it fresh, and reward you for staying with the game. So on the whole while i wouldn't classify Defender's Quest as one of my favorite games, it does get a soft recommendation from me.

												Buy this game now.  It's an extremely solid indie title that can prove quite addicting. In addition, t's the first game I've ever played that made grinding levels fun (and I HATE grinding in video games).  Mostly this is because going back to old areas on harder difficulties means you'll be fighting different monsters, so oftentimes you'll have to drastically change your strategy to beat the same stage.  On top of that, the difficulty can be finely tuned according to your tastes and playstyle (Want faster/slower xp gains?  Less/more penalties for failing?) WHILE you're playing the game, so the game never gets boring or feels frustratingly hard.

content:
Posted: December 23, 2012
												This is an AMAZING game. It is an RPG Tower Defence. Instead of towers, you have a party of people, which are put in to 6 different classes. You only get a max of 6 of each class, so placing them on the lvls more important than other tower defence games.As a bonus, everyone in your party gets XP even if they were not put out, which makes getting those lvl 1 guys you just got up to a lvl that they can be helpful much easier. Each party member has their own lvl as well, and each class has 5 different skills they can use in total. However, when on a lvl, you must 'boost' them to get access to the high lvl skills. This, in turn, makes the game very strategic. Do you put a few of your people out, and boost them to Max at the start, or do you put more people out, and only boost them to lvl 2 or 3. If you like Tower Defence games, and are looking for a challenge, then this game is right up your ally. And, as a bonuses, the story as actually pretty dam good too. XDThere is aslo a Game + mode, witch I am yet to start, so that will be interesting when I get around to starting it.

content:
Posted: December 21, 2013
												Tower defense is not at all my jam, but Defender's Quest adds enough other stuff (and pulls of the defense part painlessly enough) that I've ended up really liking it. I'm only about halfway through, but, well, I was only expecting to dip my toes into it when I launched it today, and instead it ate up most of my evening.Essentially it's tower defense game with RPG mechanics and a story. Like, a proper story, that gives most RPGs a run for the their money.  That and the RPG mechanics give an attachment to your characters (who act as the "towers"), and a sense of progression, that make this game so much more than most tower defense games. The game seems to reward focusing on a small but powerful party, and I just find "making my friends way better at murder" more rewarding than "build a bunch of catapults." Also, it's pretty funny.There are a few problems; the art for the cutscenes is pretty bad (although the pixel art in battle is pretty charming.) Some of the humor falls flat or, more often, breaks character. And adding the pointless subtitle didn't make the name any less generic. Still, it's overall a fun and addicting experience.

content:
Posted: December 23, 2012
												This is an AMAZING game. It is an RPG Tower Defence. Instead of towers, you have a party of people, which are put in to 6 different classes. You only get a max of 6 of each class, so placing them on the lvls more important than other tower defence games.As a bonus, everyone in your party gets XP even if they were not put out, which makes getting those lvl 1 guys you just got up to a lvl that they can be helpful much easier. Each party member has their own lvl as well, and each class has 5 different skills they can use in total. However, when on a lvl, you must 'boost' them to get access to the high lvl skills. This, in turn, makes the game very strategic. Do you put a few of your people out, and boost them to Max at the start, or do you put more people out, and only boost them to lvl 2 or 3. If you like Tower Defence games, and are looking for a challenge, then this game is right up your ally. And, as a bonuses, the story as actually pretty dam good too. XDThere is aslo a Game + mode, witch I am yet to start, so that will be interesting when I get around to starting it.

number of helpful: 0 of 1 people (0%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: December 21, 2013
												Tower defense is not at all my jam, but Defender's Quest adds enough other stuff (and pulls of the defense part painlessly enough) that I've ended up really liking it. I'm only about halfway through, but, well, I was only expecting to dip my toes into it when I launched it today, and instead it ate up most of my evening.Essentially it's tower defense game with RPG mechanics and a story. Like, a proper story, that gives most RPGs a run for the their money.  That and the RPG mechanics give an attachment to your characters (who act as the "towers"), and a sense of progression, that make this game so much more than most tower defense games. The game seems to reward focusing on a small but powerful party, and I just find "making my friends way better at murder" more rewarding than "build a bunch of catapults." Also, it's pretty funny.There are a few problems; the art for the cutscenes is pretty bad (although the pixel art in battle is pretty charming.) Some of the humor falls flat or, more often, breaks character. And adding the pointless subtitle didn't make the name any less generic. Still, it's overall a fun and addicting experience.

number of helpful: 0 of 1 people (0%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: January 26, 2014
												The first tower defense game I played was Desktop Tower Defense, a simple game that is on a grid and sends wave after wave of enemy at you.  This was a fun game mechanic and it would pop up with different themes in different games through the years. But, it was not until Defender’s Quest: Valley of the Forgotten that I found a game that used that mechanics to great effect in an Role Playing Game fashion.The opening of the game shows you as the main character being dragged out of her house and thrown into the Pit. She has the plague but also realizes she has special powers.  From here it opens the ability to play the game.  She can bring warriors into the Half-Way Realm and allow them to kill the revenants, monsters people turn into after they die of the plague. The story starts taking twists from there as you follow what has really been happening to two kingdoms and what the ultimate goal is.There are a host of characters that arrive in the game and each comes with their own personality.  The first people you find are barbarians, who wear no armor and are humorously suicidal in their combat tactics. Then you meet the rangers, who are far more practical about their need for survival. Each of the units you meet have a person who is going to be seen in cut scenes and helps give you a feel of the personality of that unit.Each of the units levels up, gains new skills, and can even be upgraded with new equipment.  Most of this is done in towns.  When in a town you can recruit units you have access to, but need to keep a close eye on the cost as the more units you have, the higher the price for the next one.  Gear comes in two main forms armor and weapons. There are also things that your main character can equip, but those mainly augment her abilities and are not purchasable.  When a character gains experience they level up just like you would expect in a normal RPG. Each unit has a skill tree with two branches. This means one barbarian might do a lot more damage and another might recover from wounds faster, it is up to you how you want them to work.This game was not  anywhere on my radar and that is sad because it is a great game.  The units seem well thought out so as to be different and fit a certain use at a certain time. The story told through still frames is well done with attention to facial expressions and a great sense of humor. This game is a great one, and the team at Level Up Labs is already working on another.

number of helpful: 0 of 1 people (0%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: January 26, 2014
												Though I may not be one to play many tower defense games, this one has really grasped my attention. At first glance, it may look like a bit of a low graphic, and average drawn out sprites/characters, but that's not where the game is supposed to shine. Even the, the story is surprisingly detailed, and you learn to appreciate the characters. Where it shines most is the gameplay itself! A great game to have in windowed mode while doing other things, it's a pleasant distraction, very refreshing, and easy to learn. There is a ton of depth with characters having their own skill trees, each defensive unit becoming special in their own way. It has good areas to level up quickly if you want to power up, but it doesn't feel necessary. In fact, the game has a good pace, and you could pick it up and play just a few minutes, or a few hours! The ability to slow down, pause, or speed up combat is so pleasing to have also, allowing me to follow a flow I'm comfortable with, never too pressured, but always leaving you thinking. I highly recommend it for the price, and tower defense lover would enjoy this, and even those new or not keen on the genre will feel comfortable with it. I know I was!

content:
Posted: December 20, 2013
												As far as tower defense games go, I normally play them a little bit and then grow board of them. That was not the case with Defender's Quest. I've found myself unknowingly playing for hours. As with all TD games, you raise your heroes, while managing your resources. After battle, you gain EXP which levels your heroes up and scrap (gold) to buy equipment to make them even stronger.You can easily choose to play with an army (up to 6 of each hero) or you can play with only the main hero from each class for an extra challenge. For those who dislike grinding for exp and gold, you will be pleased to know they have included an option to boost the exp and gold gain by 300%.I highly suggest this game if you enjoy TD games.

content:
Posted: January 26, 2014
												Never expected this much from this game.As usual I logged on Steam and found this on sale with just 1.49 USD.Looking at the screenshots it seems like it has some RPG-maker graphics and it is a tower defense game.Man I am really not a fan of tower defense but after scrolling down the review section I see a lot of thumbs up; so I decided to give it a try.And it sucks.... ME IN!The game plays like traditional tower defense, with RPG elements like levelling up, buying armour and upgrading skills.This gives a feeling of progression since in more traditional tower defense game its all about strategy. Every battle is a new battle, nothing carries on to the next level.In this game, your heros are permanent allies. You recruit them from towns, form your own little army and grow them accordingly to your preference. Story wise its ok and the dialogues are funny at times. The presentation of the whole game is quite neat and easy on the eyes so you dont get alot of useless stuff displaying to you.There seems to be quite alot of levels as well as a new game plus where you get unique stuff and enemies which adds replayable value.The only downside is that it seems the skill tree could get some more diversity. Like it would be awesome if a standard warrior can have different styles or something.But all in all this is a solid game and is definitely worth grabbing during this 1.49 USD sale. The fun far exceeds the cost. But if you missed the sale and it goes back to 14.99, I would recommend you to think twice before buying.

												The first tower defense game I played was Desktop Tower Defense, a simple game that is on a grid and sends wave after wave of enemy at you.  This was a fun game mechanic and it would pop up with different themes in different games through the years. But, it was not until Defender’s Quest: Valley of the Forgotten that I found a game that used that mechanics to great effect in an Role Playing Game fashion.The opening of the game shows you as the main character being dragged out of her house and thrown into the Pit. She has the plague but also realizes she has special powers.  From here it opens the ability to play the game.  She can bring warriors into the Half-Way Realm and allow them to kill the revenants, monsters people turn into after they die of the plague. The story starts taking twists from there as you follow what has really been happening to two kingdoms and what the ultimate goal is.There are a host of characters that arrive in the game and each comes with their own personality.  The first people you find are barbarians, who wear no armor and are humorously suicidal in their combat tactics. Then you meet the rangers, who are far more practical about their need for survival. Each of the units you meet have a person who is going to be seen in cut scenes and helps give you a feel of the personality of that unit.Each of the units levels up, gains new skills, and can even be upgraded with new equipment.  Most of this is done in towns.  When in a town you can recruit units you have access to, but need to keep a close eye on the cost as the more units you have, the higher the price for the next one.  Gear comes in two main forms armor and weapons. There are also things that your main character can equip, but those mainly augment her abilities and are not purchasable.  When a character gains experience they level up just like you would expect in a normal RPG. Each unit has a skill tree with two branches. This means one barbarian might do a lot more damage and another might recover from wounds faster, it is up to you how you want them to work.This game was not  anywhere on my radar and that is sad because it is a great game.  The units seem well thought out so as to be different and fit a certain use at a certain time. The story told through still frames is well done with attention to facial expressions and a great sense of humor. This game is a great one, and the team at Level Up Labs is already working on another.

content:
Posted: January 26, 2014
												Though I may not be one to play many tower defense games, this one has really grasped my attention. At first glance, it may look like a bit of a low graphic, and average drawn out sprites/characters, but that's not where the game is supposed to shine. Even the, the story is surprisingly detailed, and you learn to appreciate the characters. Where it shines most is the gameplay itself! A great game to have in windowed mode while doing other things, it's a pleasant distraction, very refreshing, and easy to learn. There is a ton of depth with characters having their own skill trees, each defensive unit becoming special in their own way. It has good areas to level up quickly if you want to power up, but it doesn't feel necessary. In fact, the game has a good pace, and you could pick it up and play just a few minutes, or a few hours! The ability to slow down, pause, or speed up combat is so pleasing to have also, allowing me to follow a flow I'm comfortable with, never too pressured, but always leaving you thinking. I highly recommend it for the price, and tower defense lover would enjoy this, and even those new or not keen on the genre will feel comfortable with it. I know I was!

I've found myself unknowingly playing for hours. As with all TD games, you raise your heroes, while managing your resources. After battle, you gain EXP which levels your heroes up and scrap (gold) to buy equipment to make them even stronger.You can easily choose to play with an army (up to 6 of each hero) or you can play with only the main hero from each class for an extra challenge. For those who dislike grinding for exp and gold, you will be pleased to know they have included an option to boost the exp and gold gain by 300%.I highly suggest this game if you enjoy TD games.

												Buy this game now.  It's an extremely solid indie title that can prove quite addicting. In addition, t's the first game I've ever played that made grinding levels fun (and I HATE grinding in video games).  Mostly this is because going back to old areas on harder difficulties means you'll be fighting different monsters, so oftentimes you'll have to drastically change your strategy to beat the same stage.  On top of that, the difficulty can be finely tuned according to your tastes and playstyle (Want faster/slower xp gains?  Less/more penalties for failing?) content:
Posted: November 15, 2015
												My previous experience with playing a tower defense game was for free one for couple of hours on a relative's iPad and an hour of the original Plants vs. Zombies. I know. The story and mechanics of this game are fantastic. The progression is balanced - I like that you can reassign experience points on the leveling (tech) tree. Once your characters are all leveled up, they still have most of the abilities that you want. Towards the end of the 2nd quest there are some 3 star levels that feel nigh impossible, but those are the exception and I am sure plenty of people have been able to beat them. On those hard levels the placement of characters has to be meticulously planned to counter the relentlessness and special abilities of the enemy waves. I highly recommend this game. It is a shame that there are not more well made 2D tower defense games on Steam.

number of helpful: 0 of 1 people (0%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: December 7, 2015
												Many people called this a "tower defense with RPG elements" at first I didn't know what that meant but it pretty much describes the game perfectly. Azra is the leader who can cast spells and also boost defenders - there are 6 types of defenders that have their unique abilities and advantages. While you boost the characters in battle, there also is a leveling up system in which you also add points to certain skills which actually adds a lot of depth to the game - it makes you think about what is mostly valuable of each defender and if you boost them enough for a certain skill to be used.Some enemies go straight for Azra, some try to get Azra but attack defenders along the way, some are fast, some are slow, some have armor, some have an insane amount of hit points. The come in waves from different locations in different amounts.It all sounds pretty basic, right? What makes this game so special is that it introduces new variables and level designs at just the right pace; there is never too much of one thing in the game, it's never a grind, it's never repetitious. The levels were never frustrating when they were heard either; it always just made me think hard about a better defense, who should get boosted and where I need to reposition during the battle. The idea of making something challenging without making frustrating is something they absolutely nailed on this game. On the flipside, if you are convinced you have everything figured out for your defense and even need to watch - just fast foward with the 2x or 4x button (this small feature is amazing).If you want to go back and play the battles at a high difficulty, you can do that too, which I also found the be very fun (the higher difficulty didn't just add more enemies - it also changed what types of enemies and even changes the entry points. Once again, they did a great job of preventing this game from feeling like repetitious).The game has an accompanying story which is kind of funny sometimes. I enjoyed the animations mostly and they were well done. A minor complaint of mine would be that the humor bits would take over the unfolding of the story occasionally and got in the way. I don't feel like the story development was conitinuous enough.The music was pretty enjoyable and fitting for the game. I will say some of the songs seemed like they were ripped from Nobuo Uematsu (Final Fantasy I - X, Chrono Trigger) but he is the GOAT. Highly recommended.

content:
Posted: June 15, 2016
												There isn't much that hasn't already been said about this game, so I'm not going to write a super long review.DQ:VF is a very fun Tower Defense-RPG hybrid game.  I bought it with hesitation, very unsure of if I'd like it or not.  It's loads of fun, the story seems good so far, the characters are detailed with their own histories and little quips they say to each other, sometimes humorous.  The gameplay itself works like most TD games except you place heroes that act as your towers, and they can level up and learn new active/passive skills.  Outside of battle you can also equip them with different gear to give them better offense/defense.I got this game after they came out with the Deluxe edition (mainly upgraded visuals) and I'm glad I did.  I'm sort of a visual person, and I like what I'm playing to be pretty and polished.  I'm not sure I would have enjoyed the Standard version as much, but this free visual upgrade to Deluxe is awesome and well done.According to their website the devs have already started working on a DA:VF 2 and I'm pretty excited about it.  I'll definitely look into it as more info is released and most likely buy it.This is one of the best TD/RPG hybrids I've ever played.  The gameplay is light and fun, and you can tell they put a LOT of time into the story and characters.8-9/10 Would highly recommend.

content:
Posted: March 12, 2014
												An excellent tower defense game that is traditional in all the ways I love but innovative where it counts. Instead of placing towers, you're placing party members. Like a traditional TD game, there are resource points you acquire within a round that you can spend on placing new towers (i.e. allies) or buffing the towers you've already placed. In Defender's Quest, this resource is called "PSI", which is essentially the "mana" of Azra (aka: you, the commander).  Howevever, Defender's Quest also gives you two other resources to spend BETWEEN rounds: gold and experience. Experience is used to unlock abilities on an ally's skill tree, thereby making them available to use in battle. (Each skill is assigned a power level and is not available in battle until you buff this ally to that level using PSI points.)Gold is used to hire new allies into the party or to purchase armor/weapon upgrades for individual allies, which immediately and permanently boosts their stats (i.e. unlike skill upgrades, these are conferred immediately at the start of battle---no PSI points required.)Every level can be replayed as many times as you want to farm XP and gold, and every level has multiple difficulty settings that earn you better gold/XP rewards for beating them. (There is no penalty for running away.) Beating the highest difficulty on some levels earns you a legendary weapon or armor, far more powerful than anything you'll find in shops.The only bad thing I could possibly say about the game is that the art in the cutscenes makes the game's aesthetic somewhat comparable to something you'd find on a flash portal. By flash portal standards, the artwork is amazing. By overall industry standards, the art seems a little amateur. The in-game art is pixely and SNES-tastic. I criticize only the cutscene art here. But in the end, it doesn't even really matter, because the cutscenes have no effect on gameplay, and you can even skip over them all if you like. The game itself is A+.If you like Tower Defense, it's one of the better TD games in the Steam catalogue.

content:
Posted: November 11, 2014
												An enjoyable tower defense game with RPG elements.  (Characters level up and have skill trees that carry over, although you can reassign points for a fee.) The need to "gold star" everything keeps this game replayable for quite a long time, and there's a challenge to complete the game in its hard mode without the many generic units you can hire, making the game extremely difficult at times. (In fact, functionally impossible at the hardest versions of some levels. Fortunately, you don't need 100% completion for those.) The game is also pausable, for those who find some tower defense games too frantic to enjoy.  There are some points where you really need to set the game to slow-mo and pump out the spells you get as their cooldowns time out just to cling to life for another wave, though.  It can, however, chug when you get to very high levels, and have INSANE numbers of effects going on at once.  I've also had it crash from a memory overflow from having too many sprites on the field in one of the "endless" maps where they just send infinite units your way.  Beyond that one flaw, (which you can avoid by just not trying to play the endless mode truly endlessly,) it's a great game.  I highly recommend.

												At first I was not 100% sure about buying or passing mostly owing to the simple art style and the fact its a tower defense which are a dime a dozen now days, however after looking at reviews and seeing some high praise and checking the forms and seeing active Dev's interacting with the community decided to give it a try.The first thing I met was a user agreement which is fairly common now days however unlike others I actually read it was very simple and easy to understand made a nice impression and told me about their attention to detail before even accessing the first screen of the game, this attention to detail was further proven once within the game the customization in just the options menu alone warrants this game being noticeable, I can't say if you will find it worth your money but if you have a few bucks burning a hole in your pocket or see this on sale (well worth full price in my opinion) grab it.This game and its Developers are like a Unicorn in this day and age they clearly care about their players and the product itself Will be keeping a eye out for future releases from them.If you have any doubts look at a few of the stickied threads to see the developers love for the community and the game, and notice that to date there are 377 Positive reveiws and only two negative :P

content:
Posted: November 25, 2014
												First off, I do recommend this game when it drops to around 5 bucks at most. I picked this game up on sale. At 15 dollars, no, this game is not worth it at all.This is a simple tower defense game which only occupies a few screens across the entire game. Really isn't much to it. Feels like you are playing in a room or two.The game is woefully unbalanced. For 90% of the game you can breeze by with only using Archers playing each level on it's hardest difficulty. This also means beating the game and then playing in game in it's second quest, which is just a repea of the game but harder. Problem is, the game is mostly a cakewalk until the end of the second quest where you hit this wall. And that is where the main problem is....Grinding. FOr some odd reason this game has you grinding. This game takes Tower Defense and ads the worst element from an MMO - Grinding. Now, to beat the game I have to grind the same maps over and over and over, jsut to beat the final few levels.Overall, did you find this while it had a 5 dollar price tag like I did? Buy it. It's fun up until the grinding hits. Did you find this game as it's full, overblown 15 dollar price tag? Avoid it completely.

content:
Posted: October 11, 2014
[UPDATE: Less-amateur art, less-trash performance... still just a clicker.]Enjoyable at first, in the end, only tedious. No real challenge... or even tower defense.Where most tower defense makes you think about how best to place towers and what to upgrade when, this game is completely stripped of thought. You learn the optimal locations for each "tower" type early on, and, as evidenced by "hero mode", the levels are almost all designed with a choke or two that takes full advantage of a single group's optimal patterns, so most levels play like this:1. Plug one, rarely two, "tower" groups into obvious optimal sockets locations OPTIONAL: Spam archers2. Upgrade (Mostly whenever, you'll have plenty of 'power'.)3. WINThe "RPG" side certainly gives math nerds something to obsess over, but it's similarly simplistic:1. Level up!2. Damage +1 OPTIONAL: Reset points at any time, because you somehow screwed that upThat's it. You want your healers to heal, of course, (skip Holy Light completely) and to take advantage of each "tower's" secondary effects, (armor break, chill, bleed, range, light/blind, devour) but for the most part, you'll just have to decide which usually low-end skill or two to neglect. Usually the lowest. You can safely ignore most defensive skills. (The actual numbers are utterly pointless because adequate info to calculate DPS and some secondary interactions aren't provided, and you learn how effective everything is by "feel"/sight same as any TD game anyways... but don't tell the math nerds!)And that's the game for you. The art is bland, the story is absurd, but occaisionally amusing. Nothing to see here. While not a "worst game ever", if you're out for an actually good tower defense/game, look elsewhere. You might enjoy this if you're a math nerd, part of the Number Enlargement crowd, or just want something easy and amusing to click on and only plan to throw a few hours away with it anyways. Don't expect the game to get better as it goes on, it just doesn't. It never could, because it's fundamentally flawed.[FOR OLD VERSION:] Unfortunately, I have to add: system requirements are a trollishly bad joke. The game runs in Flash/AIR and suffers from the usual "looks like an old DOS machine could run it/practically requires a super-computer" issues. On a less powerful CPU, it may take twice as long to get the same amount done, and you will lose input control if you button-mash the one spell you'll want to button mash. But don't worry, you'll only notice it at critical moments, and only cause you to lose your "perfect" completion on a couple 45 minute boss battles... before you learn. Or your RSI flares up.

content:
Posted: January 26, 2014
												Defender's Quest is a Tower-Defense/RPG Hybrid (Think Final Fantasy Tactics meets Tower Defense).Defender's Quest tightly focuses on three things: tactical depth, customization, and story. That means no random encounters, no spikey-haired emo kids, no forced time sinks, and no tedious, repetitive battles.The battle system builds off of tower defense, with individual characters taking the place of towers. Each character levels-up, learns skills, and equips gear individually, allowing the player to customize their battle experience and strategy. The overall game structure is similar to "tactical" RPG's, but with a real-time battle system. Game speed is adjustable, and commands can even be issued while the game is paused.It also features an engaging, character-driven story written by an actual English major! The story strives to be fast-paced, snappy, and always relevant to gameplay. Events and dialogue explain things as they become relevant to the player, minimizing exposition. Finally, it's got options and accessibility settings out the wazoo, so that you can have the best possible experience!

content:
Posted: May 8, 2015
												The game has me hooked, but it has severe design flaws. The game plays in a small window. Being able to tell your units what type of enemy to target is nice, but the interface looks like a Windows 3.1 era spreadsheet program. It's too easy to spend money on the wrong upgrades and then not be sure if you're playing a level wrong or you just need to grind. (I got crushed on Karsk repeatedly until I figured out that I needed to go back to the last town and buy my main ranger a bow). The interface is so sloppy that you don't even get an error message when you try to spend a skill point on something you don't have the requirements for, it just makes the normal sound but does nothing. Each character you recruit is a different class, but you can recruit additional mute copies of the class who you level up separately which is... messy. Is there any other game where "boosts" don't have a time limit?The two Soulcaster games did the whole "Tower Defence where your 'towers' are people" with better art, music, and gameplay.

content:
Posted: June 30, 2013
												7/10 DQ is a tower defense game. Don't gimme that look: this one's actually unique with its own personality. DQ mixes RPG into the blend as well with character trees, equipment, and classes. Your "party members" serve as your towers. The story is pretty good; a lot better than most games of this genre. The writing is awesome and there's a lot to do/see.  Combat is fun, but there's no depth to it. Once you get gear and the basics, you snowball from half way onward, plowing through everything near-effortlessly. The game also suffers bizarre frame drops. Seeing that this game's graphics are 16+ bit, it's inexcusable to have to compensate for input lag on such an undemanding game.  The price is also a bit high. If you can find it on sale, definately pick up DQ!

number of helpful: 25 of 59 people (42%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: September 26, 2014
												Defender's Quest is a case study in covering your weaknesses and emphasizing your strengths. Shoddy writing? A beautiful "skip" button in every cutscene and dialogue can be turned off. Difficulty? If you hit a brick wall in story mode you can go back and do slightly harder versions of prior maps to level up. Tower diversity? Unique equipment means your second Berserker probably won't be as good as your first, so it's harder to spam one tower. The slog of New Game+ not going fast enough? Triple experience is an option in the menus. All this lets you focus on the core tower defense game, which is best played at 4X speed.Plenty of weaknesses can't be worked around, though. Workshop mods are few in number, and the first one I tried locked up the game in the first level. Character level is too huge a factor in whether you pass a level or not, meaning few maps feel appropriately scaled to your level at any given time. The game has a fixed resolution, even in fullscreen, and in fullscreen Steam notifications will leave artifacts on the screen. It's a little too easy to fall into a "two of each" mentality, setting up two identical sets of towers on the two major paths of most maps, with the only major variance between maps being what towers you level up first. The tower "skill trees" don't contribute much especially for those towers that only have variants of "melee attack" or "shoot arrows". For all the weaknesses I've pointed out, there are few high points in the game. The boss fights are excellent, requiring you to balance "kill the boss faster" against "kill the creeps faster". Otherwise it's the usual tower-defense game of setting up your towers and watching them slaughter thousands of zombies. The game demands enough of your attention in boosting your towers etcetera that it's not a good "put something on in the background while you play" game, but isn't demanding enough to be a thoughtful or engaging experience.All in all, it's hard to recommend Defender's Quest unless you're just dying for a tower defense game where you make a bunch of bars go up a la Progress Quest.

												First of all, I can’t recommend this game.After the overwhelming reviews, I was really happy to finally see another good tower defense game. What did I get, a bland, mediocre and basic game…….What are my reasons for my harsh criticism??Here are Two:1. Characters and Story, are just badly written. For instance the Berserker: he likes shoes and fighting, that’s the whole character, no real backstory, no real emotions, no nothing.......Ok no character has a real backstory in this game or any real emotional turmoil.2. The game mechanics are so basic, you have 6!!! Different types of Towers…….Equipment is uninteresting because every item is just a stat boost in the same attributes, +1 Sword, +2 Sword, for example.The skill System is ok, but it doesn’t have a big impact in fights. Sure it changes your tactics a little but it’s not a big difference. Granted DD games aren’t known for their good writing and often mechanics in these games are basic. But to give a game like this overwhelmingly good Reviews ??????? WHY ?????Its ok, its decent, on a 1-10 I would give it 5 or 6. But for God damn 14 bucks I can’t recommend buying this game!!!!! (Maybe for 2.99).

Posted: June 27, 2013
												I absolutely love Defender's Quest Valley of the Forgotten. When I read tower defence rpg I was a little lost. I have never heard of the two being combined and wondered how it could be done. The rpg side of this game is based around the story of Azra; Azra is a royal librarian who found herself in the forgotten zone - a plague ridden part of the kingdom and things went crazy. Along the way Azra met people to aid her in her journy to find out what is going on. People like Slak and khetti (names can be changed I kept them default though). the players met along your journy become your towers and placed in a standard tower defence way, slak for example is a berserker who slashes and slaughters light hp targets, and khetti is an archer. The characters are leveld up over time so the player can equip them with gear and put points into skills such as slaks flurry to hit 5 targets at once. Now back to Azra; since the game revolves around her what role does this librarian play. Well in combat you are summoned to the spirit world to kill the plague ridden posessed citizens. Azra levels up with your characters so she can cast damage spells, buffs, and heals to your people during combat. The heal is very advantagous because your people will die. . . HOWEVER they can be resummoned. To prevent deaths one of the options is to equip them with armor which can be purchased and unlocked at certain points in the game along with other mercenaries.overall I rate this game 5/5  due to the 5 dollar sale price during steam weekly sale and the unique story and combat. The game also supports the steam workshop so that you can continue the game with player made levels which I have not tried yet.For the cons of this game I have not found any but some players might be turned off by the non applicable voice acting, all of the narrating is texted out.

Posted: July 12, 2013
												If you like retro games and tower defense games, this is both in one with a slight twist. Instead of towers, you recruit different hero types to join your party, who you can gradually level up and train/upgrade skills, then place them strategically for best effect.Linear gameplay (you go from point to point, following the storyline, which is fairly long in itself), and for the completionist in you, there's the chance to go back and replay each level on different difficulties for better rewards. Well worth the money.

Posted: December 24, 2012
												This is the Best tower defense game I ever played.  Is it the best ever? Probably not.  It is a tower defense with set paths on every map, no path customizing (altering) at all which i would say is a strategic element required for it to be the best ever.  But it does have an actual story which makes sense of enemies getting to the goal point, never seen that in a TD game. Story is ok, some good humor, skill trees for units who gain persistent levels, over 10 hours of gameplay on initial game mode (far more if you want to unlock everything), and after beating it it unlocks a different and harder game mode.  All these things combined give this game far more depth and play time then any TD game I've played and I've played quite a few. It could be made better and I am hoping for a sequel. This game is worth 10 bucks if its up your alley, 7 or so if you arent sure. It's already been cheaper though.

Posted: May 7, 2014
												Great game, doesn't cost much, and has some great content. A nice spin on the tower defense genre, with a great difficulty curve. New game + is excellent, as it provides a whole new challenge to the game, and side quests that flesh out the story a bit and add new abilities to the enemies, forcing you to try new strategies. Especially for the cost, this game is well worth it. Edit: Also, the story and characters are actually pretty good, and there's some great humor in there as well.

Posted: April 21, 2014
												Clever is the word for this game.  The gameplay is tight, well-balanced, and clever.  Tower defense games are rarely this clever and the RPG system rewards good play.  The downfall of virtually all RPG systems is a sense of grind - you want the best stuff, you're going to have to perform repetitive tasks until you've got the prerequisite numbers.  Grinding reminds me of a job.  Defender's Quest lets you bypass that - anything you'd have to grind for is optional, and if you want the optional content, then you can toggle the exp and gold gain.  This also lets you set the difficulty to as difficult or as easy as you want.The amazing thing is that the gameplay is so good, and the rest of the game is also so good.  The graphics aren't the modern blockbusters, but the character art is charming and clever, and the dialog is well-written and allows you to connect to the characters.  Fun gameplay, thoughtful gameplay, good art, good dialog, fun plot.  The game can even be replayed, and the new game+ has additional insight into the world if you're that hooked.  It also ramps up the difficulty if you like a challenge.  To top it off, the game is inexpensive.  Why have you not already bought it?

Posted: June 24, 2014
												This is a diamond in the rough for tower defense games. There are six different classes of units, and you can recuit a maximum of six units per class. Each level has four difficulties and three stars. There's an overarching plot to tie the levels together. Some levels require strategic use of only certain units, and level layouts are such that you are forced to thoughtfully place units to maximize their contribution. Item upgrades were added recently, and New Game+ mode keeps the fun going for more than twice as long as the original game. I've played this game for a long time, since before it even landed on steam, and I still haven't acquired the highest level items. I still haven't finished beating levels. I still haven't gotten my fill of this fun game.

												Second or Third most enjoyable Tower Defense game I've ever played.  And probably the deepest and most clever.  It actually does successfully combine a RPG with a TD game. Posted: July 22, 2014
												Simple, inexpensive indie TD with a nice twist. Each "tower" is a character and levels, equips and spends skill points independently. The campaign has a nice length to it. I'm not finished, but I'm over 20 battles. Each battle also has multiple difficulties that give greater rewards, including unlocking bonus missions.The native resolution is tiny, probably 800x600 if not 640x480 and there is no way to increase it in windowed mode that I can see. Also the generic characters you make have the potential to be clones of your main heroes, each class' talent tree provides customization but (at least at low levels) leaves little advantage to stray. It would be nice if each character could learn different active skills from their brethren that share a class.There is a sequel in the works and I look forward to it. It would appear they are addressing my main issues and thensome.Bottom line, I'm enjoying this title and while I'm a sale hound, if I had paid full-price I wouldn't have been disappointed. If you are not a huge TD fan, this may leave little to desire.

Posted: September 20, 2014
												Defender's Quest is an extremely fun and addicting tower defense/RPG hybrid.  There are so many viable strategies for you to experiment with.  The way you can get your different characters to work with each other is very deep with different talent trees to choose from, weopons and armor to collect and level up, spells for your main character to choose from, and placement of your troops.   I found it very enjoyable and satisfying to beat both the normal game and the new game plus (hard mode) first in "hero" mode where you only use the characters introduced in the main story line and then go back to recruit extra troops to tackle some of the more advanced extreme difficulties.  There is an interesting storyline to follow.  The dialog between the characters has a sometimes wacky sense of humor that I really enjoyed, while the overall storyline was still serious.  I thought they struck a nice balance.  While the game may look simplistic in graphic design, the experience is anything but and I got my money's worth many times over.  Just a very fun game and well worth your time if you have even a passing interest in either RPG's or good tower defense games.  Greatly looking forward to the sequel that is in development!

Posted: June 19, 2014
												As a puzzle game, I think its better than the likes of Puzzle Quest, because you're essentially managing a party of heroes, and placing them in dungeon sets and hoping that your customisations and placements pay off. It doesn't hinge on playing a very abstract match 3 game. Its a hybrid of an adventuring party management game, and a battle based puzzler. The fact that it sort of follows Tower Defense rules, in that you have waves of enemies, and they follow known paths, is all by the by. Goblin hordes usually follow dungeon tunnels anyway as they charge the brave adventurers!  I've played my fair share of Tower Defense games and hundreds of them bore me to tears, but this one seems to get the balance between RPG party management and planning, and the try it and then refine it mechanic. It's not overly complex, each class (and there are about six in total, I think) have skill trees that are only two branches. You need to earn money (loot and scrap) to purchase more adventurers to sign up. Then you have to train them up from level 1, and customise their skillsets to complement the team you already have.There are beserkers who lend the chopping/slashing muscle - for corner killzones - and your archers can thin out the horde on the way, as well as try and catch the speedy monsters early. You also have (so far) Ice mages, for slowing effects and mages for healing or area of effect spells. You can specialise zerkers as damage soakers or fast dps dealers. You can specialise archers as heavy critical hitter, or speedy bleeders. Plus you've got the inventory to manage with different armours and weapons etc. Some of the harder levels later on in the story, require a little bit of farming to get enough money and people to do them. It just hit a sweet spot for me, in terms of low maintenance RPG adventuring, with just enough tweaking, twiddling and puzzling to keep me going back to it over and over again. Repeating the same levels with harder foes doesn't seem to get old, you have to adjust your tactics for a longer harder game. All the while you're crafting up a team whose skills work intimately with each other, making the sum of the parts greater than the individual.

Posted: February 14, 2014
												I always had a certain fondness for tower defense. In StarCraft, I'd spend more time stacking cannons than playing the ladder, and Team Fortress 2's MvM mode reveals a certain primal fun of killing tons of heartless, unfeeling dudes. To that end, Defender's Quest: Valley of the Forgotten presents a well-rounded, core dude-killing experience, but the cracks in the polish are evident.You're given six classes to play, all fairly standard for the genre: heavy damage, light damage, healer, ranged, status effects, and tank. Upgrade trees for each class are fleshed out for the game's length, and most powers are distinct from the moment you first receive them. Leveling up your characters before and during battle using "Psi" adds a certain urgency to the fight, and doesn't feel forced.But between battles there exists some friction between the player and the imperfect interface. Between the fast-forward of battle and the clunky number-comparison engine to power up your party, you'll be wishing for a patch to streamline or automate the process. You could do worse but you could do better; not even trendy not-loading-but-loading-messages like 'reticulating splines' or 'powering up the thermal core' are to be seen. You might hope to find some solace in the story, but it's just as hacked-on as the interface and I couldn't be bothered to follow it.My first playthrough entailed of spamming rangers (long-range) with the range upgrade and blew through the game without breaking a sweat, but in Hero Mode, where you limit yourself to one of each class, is where the game's difficulty felt most appropriate. Oftentimes you'll have three or four spawn points to deal with, and you'll need to consider the most optimal placement to cover all your bases, evoking the puzzle modes of yore.All in all I'm giving this a weak recommendation. The game itself is pretty solid - gameplay is mostly balanced, and it can be as hard as you want it to be. The lore isn't engaging and you won't miss much from skipping it; on the other hand, if you're the type for a story maybe tower defense wasn't going to be your cup of tea anyway. If it goes on sale again for 90% off you'll get a fun one-off to pick up and play, not unlike something you'd find on a phone or tablet. Otherwise, you may feel you aren't getting enough bang for your buck.

Posted: January 28, 2014
												When I first read reports about Defender's Quest and watched the initial trailer, I was expecting a pretty standard RPG plot and characters. Much to my delight, I was half-wrong. The plot might be your tried and true "unlikely hero saves the world because, well, destiny" fare, but the characters and the writing are frequently reminiscent of the humor that characterized the Penny Arcade: OTRSPOD games. One notable feature of the game is that it does engage in some of the good, old-fashioned grinding that some RPGs are famous for, but this game lets you control just how "grindy" it is, giving you control of how much XP and scrap (money) that you receive at the end of each battle. This allows players to either keep the default settings and go through the basic plot, or to turn up the rewards to max so that they don't have to spend days grinding the same level over and over for XP so that they can run the special challenges. Each level has four settings ranging from Casual, where enemies have lessened HP and damage potential, to Extreme, where you better be ready because foes will WRECK an underpowered group. Playing extreme challenges unlock rewards for your party, giving you unique equipment and larger XP and scrap rewards, so there is a reason to tackle these challenges.A new game+ feature is a welcome sight, and the fact that this mode allows you to unlock upgrades for your unique gear gives you an incentive to play again. Overall, I found the game to be fun and engaging, well worth the price of admission.

												6/10-= READ =-Don't be fooled with the rating even though I recommend this. I've spent hours analyzing while playing this game. It all boils down to several pros/cons+ You can level up your units+ You can go back to the stage you've done to train+ Each stage has different level settings and rewards so you don't have to toggle difficulty+ Different combinations to try out+ Story is funny as much as it is serious+ Multiple Endings?- Story does get boring so I'm glad theres comedy in it- After awhile, you get tired of the grind- Story is short- Once you reach that point where you're no longer playing but "working" through the game. Typical for most rpgs- Limited contentWith that said, I still recommend this game. It leaves you to wonder how much potential it has and hope the devs do a much better version next installment. It was enjoyable while it last. And don't let the price scare you. If you guys actually spent time learning how much time, effort and your own money is spent to develop the game... you wouldn't be b**ching and moaning about games being expensive. That's why you read reviews like this to help you make a better decision :P

Posted: June 17, 2015
												I want to state this as plainly as possible first: I hate pixel-art games.  I find them to be a lazy way to do art and a cheap grab for indie devs.With that said, this game is great, and it taught me that pixel-art is okay if the game mechanics make up for it, which this one does extremely well.The blend of RPG and TD is done extremely well.  The story is mediocre, but it does help the progression of the game along.There are enough RPG mechanics in this game and uniqueness among the "towers" and enemies that you will enjoy going back and doing the levels over again at higher difficulties for the loot and to level your party.If you like tower defense and you like RPGs somewhat reminiscent of classic Final Fantasy, pick this up and enjoy.

Posted: June 25, 2013
												A really nice and fun tower defense for once. It does get a bit repetetive after a while, and to beat every single achievement, but just a single playthrough might well justify the low price of it.A fun and lovely written story allows it to shine among other tower defense games out there, and I for one does not have anything to complain about the graphics. Design is good as well, and I never felt like any of my "towers" didn't have their place on a given level. In that sense I feel the game design is well thought through, and with of the difficulty depending on your skills and sense of strategy rather than random luck.The one thing that makes it an 8 or 9 out 10, rather than 10/10, would be affermentioned repetiveness. If you do decide to go for all achievements and clearing all of the levels, then prepare for quite some grinding of maps you've already cleared many times before. As such the replayability isn't all that great either, unless you simply wish to experience the same brilliant story once more.

Posted: January 10, 2013
												This is actually a pretty solid game - the troop variety could have been wider, and some of them just never are as good as the others, ultimately (archers are astounding, and dragons are cool but, ultimately, overpriced for what they offer. :( )It's really a tower defense in spirit, but has some neat little RPG elements, with some progression of your wizard/caster person, as well as your troops, who each have a little skill tree and stuff. For the price, and supporting a small studio, well worth it.Graphics are decent - the art is so so at best, the pixel work is much more pleasant than the "cutscenes", which no offense intended, are tacky at best. The story is decent, but is sorta held back by some kinda ridiculous one-liner attempts at humor and non-sequitor silliness, but all that said, I would say I enjoyed the game all in all.

Posted: September 6, 2013
												Defender's Quest is a simple turn based tower defense game.  Defenders are set up on a grid, and enemy units follow a path to the goal.  The units are well balanced and versatile, and the enemies return the favor.  You can set the pace of the battles at anytime, from a complete pause, to 4x "get this over with" speed.  You also have the option to control the difficulty to be as easy or as hard as you prefer.  Harder the challenge, the bigger the payoff.  Real strategy players are going to find the regular game a little too easy, but the game does offer unique challenges for the elite.  Gamers new to strategy games will find it very welcoming.  It is a game for every level of gamer, from casual beginner, to advanced tactician.

Posted: February 3, 2014
												Probably the best Tower Defense game I've played, ever. I've never been so engrossed in TDs since the WC3 modding era. Sprinkle in RPG elements into a TD game and you have a winning formula and a meta game that stretches beyond each stage. 												When I first saw the screenshots I though it would be confusing and just plain hard. But the trailer sold me on the idea with the idea of the story. And I must say I wasn't disappointed. Posted: February 3, 2014
												This game is quite addictive and I've been impressed with the details that provide a lot of replay value. As with any tower defense game, your goal is to prevent enemy units from reaching your tower. In this case, your tower is a librarian who has obtained magical powers to battle in the realm between life and death. To defend herself, she can cast some magic spells and she can pull her allies (berserkers, archers, healers, knights, ice mages, and dragons) into her realm and position them for defense. Besides the librarian, all units act on their own once placed. The defenders' skills and the librarian's spells can all be leveled up by earning experience. The skill trees, along with armor and weapons, provide the ability to customize each defender's strengths.What makes the game addictive is the variation. Each battle provides a different set of enemies and a different map with sometimes challenging unit placement options. As the game progresses, the type, number, and skill of available defenders increases which provides for different strategies to be employed. Each battle can also be completed at one of four difficulty levels, with higher levels producing different, more powerful, more numerous enemies. Completing battles perfectly (with no tower damage) unlocks bonus levels for additional variation. Once the main story is completed (10 - 20 hours depending on replays, bonus levels, etc.), a "Play+" option allows the story to be run again, this time with additional side quests, newly-enhanced enemies, upgraded weapons/armor, etc. The librarian's journal is also unlocked, adding some more humor to the game (which was already very light hearted in tone).

Posted: February 3, 2014
												Perhaps the best way to summarise Defender's Quest is this: "It's the most sophisticated, enjoyable and generally fun tower defence game you can find." Featuring a captivating story, interesting characters, countless extra challenges and items to get,  Defender's Quest will provide you with more hours of gameplay than you could have ever imagined you could spend in such a modest looking at first glance game. Posted: June 25, 2013
												A really nice and fun tower defense for once. It does get a bit repetetive after a while, and to beat every single achievement, but just a single playthrough might well justify the low price of it.A fun and lovely written story allows it to shine among other tower defense games out there, and I for one does not have anything to complain about the graphics. Design is good as well, and I never felt like any of my "towers" didn't have their place on a given level. In that sense I feel the game design is well thought through, and with of the difficulty depending on your skills and sense of strategy rather than random luck.The one thing that makes it an 8 or 9 out 10, rather than 10/10, would be affermentioned repetiveness. If you do decide to go for all achievements and clearing all of the levels, then prepare for quite some grinding of maps you've already cleared many times before. As such the replayability isn't all that great either, unless you simply wish to experience the same brilliant story once more.

Posted: January 10, 2013
												This is actually a pretty solid game - the troop variety could have been wider, and some of them just never are as good as the others, ultimately (archers are astounding, and dragons are cool but, ultimately, overpriced for what they offer. :( )It's really a tower defense in spirit, but has some neat little RPG elements, with some progression of your wizard/caster person, as well as your troops, who each have a little skill tree and stuff. For the price, and supporting a small studio, well worth it.Graphics are decent - the art is so so at best, the pixel work is much more pleasant than the "cutscenes", which no offense intended, are tacky at best. Posted: November 24, 2013
												Tower Defense meets RPG, and the towers are actually characters. I love how the story supports the mechanics, and the variety of personalities and their interactions. The art is colorful and stylized but the story is surprisingly deep. While there is not much branching, there's replay value in going through the battles at higher difficulties (as the monsters change, not just tougher monsters), Hero mode where you don't recruit additional soldiers (quite a challenge on some maps), and the extended replay which adds funny journal entries and weapon upgrades. Posted: January 28, 2014
												When I first read reports about Defender's Quest and watched the initial trailer, I was expecting a pretty standard RPG plot and characters. Much to my delight, I was half-wrong. The plot might be your tried and true "unlikely hero saves the world because, well, destiny" fare, but the characters and the writing are frequently reminiscent of the humor that characterized the Penny Arcade: OTRSPOD games. One notable feature of the game is that it does engage in some of the good, old-fashioned grinding that some RPGs are famous for, but this game lets you control just how "grindy" it is, giving you control of how much XP and scrap (money) that you receive at the end of each battle. This allows players to either keep the default settings and go through the basic plot, or to turn up the rewards to max so that they don't have to spend days grinding the same level over and over for XP so that they can run the special challenges. Each level has four settings ranging from Casual, where enemies have lessened HP and damage potential, to Extreme, where you better be ready because foes will WRECK an underpowered group. Playing extreme challenges unlock rewards for your party, giving you unique equipment and larger XP and scrap rewards, so there is a reason to tackle these challenges.A new game+ feature is a welcome sight, and the fact that this mode allows you to unlock upgrades for your unique gear gives you an incentive to play again. Overall, I found the game to be fun and engaging, well worth the price of admission.

Posted: February 14, 2014
												I always had a certain fondness for tower defense. In StarCraft, I'd spend more time stacking cannons than playing the ladder, and Team Fortress 2's MvM mode reveals a certain primal fun of killing tons of heartless, unfeeling dudes. To that end, Defender's Quest: Valley of the Forgotten presents a well-rounded, core dude-killing experience, but the cracks in the polish are evident.You're given six classes to play, all fairly standard for the genre: heavy damage, light damage, healer, ranged, status effects, and tank. Upgrade trees for each class are fleshed out for the game's length, and most powers are distinct from the moment you first receive them. Leveling up your characters before and during battle using "Psi" adds a certain urgency to the fight, and doesn't feel forced.But between battles there exists some friction between the player and the imperfect interface. Between the fast-forward of battle and the clunky number-comparison engine to power up your party, you'll be wishing for a patch to streamline or automate the process. You could do worse but you could do better; not even trendy not-loading-but-loading-messages like 'reticulating splines' or 'powering up the thermal core' are to be seen. You might hope to find some solace in the story, but it's just as hacked-on as the interface and I couldn't be bothered to follow it.My first playthrough entailed of spamming rangers (long-range) with the range upgrade and blew through the game without breaking a sweat, but in Hero Mode, where you limit yourself to one of each class, is where the game's difficulty felt most appropriate. Oftentimes you'll have three or four spawn points to deal with, and you'll need to consider the most optimal placement to cover all your bases, evoking the puzzle modes of yore.All in all I'm giving this a weak recommendation. The game itself is pretty solid - gameplay is mostly balanced, and it can be as hard as you want it to be. The lore isn't engaging and you won't miss much from skipping it; on the other hand, if you're the type for a story maybe tower defense wasn't going to be your cup of tea anyway. If it goes on sale again for 90% off you'll get a fun one-off to pick up and play, not unlike something you'd find on a phone or tablet. Otherwise, you may feel you aren't getting enough bang for your buck.

Posted: April 13, 2014
												Defender's Quest is a Tower-Defense/RPG Hybrid (Think Final Fantasy Tactics meets Tower Defense). Defender's Quest tightly focuses on three things: tactical depth, customization, and story. That means no random encounters, no spikey-haired emo kids, no forced time sinks, and no tedious, repetitive battles. The battle system builds off of tower defense, with individual characters taking the place of towers. Each character levels-up, learns skills, and equips gear individually, allowing the player to customize their battle experience and strategy. The overall game structure is similar to "tactical" RPG's, but with a real-time battle system. Game speed is adjustable, and commands can even be issued while the game is paused. It also features an engaging, character-driven story written by an actual English major! The story strives to be fast-paced, snappy, and always relevant to gameplay. Events and dialogue explain things as they become relevant to the player, minimizing exposition. Finally, it's got options and accessibility settings out the wazoo, so that you can have the best possible experience!

Posted: March 18, 2015
												Marrying two uniquely intricate genres of games, RPG and Tower Defense, Defender's Quest: Valley of the Forgotten displays a very well-balanced gameplay and an incredibly enticing combat system. Essentially placing stationary combatants that may be bestowed special abilities (your Towers) by investing numerical value of "Psi" into them, on a grid-like environment overlay, coming in a variety of different classes, unlocking new classes as you progress the main storyline. Each class a page out of a classic RPG history book, they each carry their own bevy of abilities based on the type (Berzerker, Archer, etc.) that will bolster your defenses either for the better or worse depending on placement and Psi investment. Characters may earn EXP by being used in battle, growing levels as the criteria becomes met and allowing the player to invest skill points into a basic (yet vital) skill tree.The overall feel of this game is very old-school, but executes sleekly by today's standards. The World Map (level select screen) features a beautiful score, quite reminiscent of early RPG soundtracks. Interestingly enough, the site for Defender's Quest 2 claims to have musical talent brought forth from none other than Nobuo Uematsu himself. One of the millions (billions?) of Final Fantasy players and avid enjoyers of their dynamic, emotionally-captivating soundtracks, this notion that an industry veteran so well known is working with an indie developer brings me hope for the future generations of gaming. Imagine the experience this renowned professional can impart upon this team, and how this team may in turn inspire Nobou Uematsu, thusly conceiving the music that highlights some of gaming's most touching and well-loved moments. Relationships like these in the game industry are vital for its continuation as the younger generations may offer fresh ideas while in turn being nurtured by the experience and wisdom of seasoned developers having been in the industry since its near-conception (decades, folks!). I sincerely hope that veteran talent continues to  reach out to budding indie developers like Level Up Labs who clearly have a passion for delivering a lasting entertainment experience that is indeed inspiring to all. I thoroughly enjoy every moment I spend playing this game, and there is a very high probability that you will, too.*Reading Rainbow Transition*

Posted: November 14, 2014
												Short: [9/10] Awesome and challenging Tower Defense x RPG mix with 30+ hours of gameplay. Only a few gripes make this game short of perfect.Long: "Defender's Quest: Valley of the Forgotten" is a Tower Defense game in which you fight hordes of enemies by using different classes and spells. The classes (of which there are 6) all differ in playstyle and give the game its RPG elements via XP gains, talent trees and weapon/armor aquisition. Even though the game looks simple, it offers a very deep combat and leveling system which will have to be adjusted multiple times in order to beat certain levels. Examples include making your archers target fastest enemies first, putting the stun sword in the hands of your knight, or making sure your ice skills don't get cancelled by your burn ones.  The story itself is amusing as well and gave me a few chuckles along the way. New Game+, 3 star rating per level, and challenges such as endless mode only extend the life of this game and make you want to play more. There are however, a few issues. Some, like the "Undo" button, which removes ALL the points you just put into your character's skill tree instead of just the last one, should be renamed "Restart" because that's what it actually does. This gets very annoying when respeccing a character with 60 points in New Game+. However, the "Undo" button is not game breaking so it doesn't change my rating of the game. What does, however, is the terrible frame drop encountered during big fights. Even though I have a very powerful rig, it has caused the game to crash several times (once while on 95th wave of endless when attempting 100 wave achievement!). Another is the poor visual of the cursor, which when coupled with the fact the frame rates drop, makes it impossible to see. This has caused me to lose a few games or constantly pause to execute commands.But the few imperfections get dwarfed by the fact this is a great game, and had me coming back for that "JUST ONE MORE ROUND" feel. The devs are actually pretty cool/active as well and respond quite frequently in the forums. Don't miss this game, it is very much worth it!   [9/10]

												This is a very simple, but fairly expansive Tower Defense (TD) game. you can gear out and upgrade your units how you want, and they all even have little tech trees for their abilities, though honestly I didn't really feel like the points I allocated did much to make any of the skills much better, but it's always fun to have that stuff I guess.The levels are different formations and the monsters spawn from different points at different times depending on the level and difficulty. You can't do any forced pathing or anything like in defense grid but you still want to place your units so that they are getting in as many hits as possible. You can also set units to specific targeting types, whether it's whatever enemy is closest to the end of the trail, the one with highest HP, lowest HP, etc...All in all this is a good little TD, I wouldn't recommend buying it unless it's on sale for like 5-8 bucks though.

												Along with Orcs Must Die and Revenge of the Titans, this is one of the few tower defense games that has managed to hold my interest at all. The only thing that is a drag on the gameplay is the fact that there are a lot of goals (completion, equipment, skill, etc.) that are far enough out of reach that you almost certainly have to grind already-completed battles over again multiple times if you're interested in more than just getting to the end as quickly as possible.

Posted: October 31, 2014
												Wow. This game really is good.I'm a bit more than halfway through as of writing this and I'm having a blast. The writing and humour is really quite good, and gameplay is nice. I find the characters really quite endearing indeed!So about the gameplay:If you've read the description, you'd know it's a tower-defense game with rpg elements; i.e. your "towers" are actually characters which level up permanently (though you still "upgrade"  them in battle). It's pretty brilliant; you can choose to grind to level them up to tackle harder levels, or you can try a no-grind approach to see if you can tough out the main missions.The gameplay is really quite smooth and although the mechanics are not anything different from other tower defense games, work really quite well.I grabbed it while it had 67% off and I feel it's well worth it, even at full price. Very well made, and I feel the creators really put their soul into this game.

Posted: October 21, 2014
												So I won this game in a giveaway where I got to choose which game I wanted out of a list, major shout out to toph--Such a nice person! Honestly this was my third choice, and it appealed to me because im a sucker for pixel art in games like this, and the old final fantasies, and man did i fall in love with this game. It's rich in story content, a great tower defense game where you can grind for currency and leveling up, and complete stages at harder difficulties to gain bonus loot, has a great soundtrack, and i swear that they sampled a battle theme from Final Fantasy 8 i swear i hear it exactly in the background of each stage with minor changes to it, which I absolutely love, I love the music in this game, the fact that you can customize the classes that you recruit, their talent tree, the fact that you can give them gear and make them stronger. This is like no other tower defense game, its got personality, as do the characters, this is no crystal defenders clone, its got its own label, in fact i think its much more elaborate and more fun than crystal defenders which I am a big fan of. All the gear customization reminds me of Fantasy Defense on Android which I was a big fan of as well. This game is defintely a gem that people should look into buying. I am so stoked for Defender's Quest 2

Posted: October 20, 2014
												Surprisingly, this game was really addictive and entertaining.  I was looking to just kill a couple hours one night a year or two ago and I expected this to be really simplistic, but it turned out to be really interesting, strategic, well designed, enjoyable, .. yeah.  I am not a thrift/indie shopper for games either, so this game catching my attention probably means its all that much more amazing.  usually I am just playing the mainstream sorta-hardcore online gamer type stuff.  10/10, 2 thumbs up,  YOU MUST TRY THIS GAME.  whether you are a casual gamer, or you are a hardcore gamer, I think this has mass appeal.  Play it for an hour, and then watch that turn into 20-30 hours and be astonished that you got addicted to a tower defense game with graphics that could be from 2000.

Posted: November 1, 2014
												One of the best tower defense games I've played so far.Rather than a typical tower defense game that you can find around steam, they insert a few interesting RPG element into the mix, and it works suprisingly well. Each tower is actually a character and each character has levels, skill trees and equipments. Each character helps progress in the main stroryline, and the storyline is pretty interesting and funny at times. Most importantly, the game runs great and destroying the waves of enemies with your smart strategic placement of towers/characters is satisfying. It has a lot of levels, multiple difficulties for each level, has bonus levels like endless mode, new game + and has Steam Workshop to add new stuff!If you're a fan of RPG and tower defense, this is definitely a game you cannot miss.8/10, great game.
